Policy_Details: Governor Carney announced Phase 2 of Delaware's reopening will begin June 15, 2020
INDIVIDUAL GUIDELINES
-Cloth coverings must be worn
-Non-household members must maximize social distancing
-All individuals in public (parks, outdoor recreation areas, shopping, etc) must social distance
-Indoor gathering limit: 50 people but social distance from non-household members
-Places operating at 30% occupancy under Phase 1 can move to 60% occupancy 
-Exercise facilities and personal care services (hair, tanning, tattoo, massage, nail, brow, spas) to remain at 30% occupancy
-Fully unenclosed outdoor gatherings of up to 250 people are permitted
-Leisure travel should be avoided but may resume under general guidance
-All vulnerable individuals should continue to shelter in place
BUSINESS GUIDELINES
-Common areas where people can congregate must remain closed
-Employees/customers have responsibility to self-quarantine if they think they may be sick
-Teleworking is encouraged
-All surfaces touched by customers must be disinfected by EPA-approved disinfectant every 15 minutes to 2 hours 
-Employees required to go to work should perform daily health work 
-All employees must wash hands throughout the day and use hand sanitizer and social distance from other employees
-Businesses must make hand sanitizer available to employees and patrons (hand sanitizer must be 60% ethanol and 70% isopropanol 
-Downtime should be given between shifts and after closing for cleaning 
-Employees must post signs about how to stop spread of COVID-19, hand hygiene, and wear a face covering  Phase Level: 2, Phase Details Source information: https://governor.delaware.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/24/2020/06/Delaware-Economic-Reopening-PHASE-2.pdf

Policy_Details: "Indoor gyms and recreation facilities remain closed, develop plans for reopening and ability to meet protocol business protocols in order to open in stage 2.  Hair salons remain closed, develop plans for reopening and ability to meet business protocols in order to open in stage 2.  	Large venues (e.g., movie theaters and sporting venues) are closed.    Restaurants dining rooms remain closed, develop plans for reopening and ability to meet business protocols in order to open in stage 2.    Bars and nightclubs remain closed."   Source information: https://rebound.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/opening-up-guidlines_rev051420.pdf

Policy_Details: Currently open: Grocery stores, pharmacies, banks and credit unions, and gas stations are all open.
Restaurants are open for take-out service only.
Stand alone retail operations are open provided they meet required safety and physical distancing guidelines. Indoor and outdoor malls are closed.
Local outdoor recreation activities are open, including many state parks.
Non-emergency medical care, dentist offices and veterinary care are open and operating, provided they meet required safety guidelines.
Local cultural, civic and faith gatherings are allowed for up to 25 people provided physical distancing can be in place.
Local social gatherings over 10 people are prohibited and those under 10 people must use physical distancing.
Personal care services such as salons and barbers, as well as gyms, are closed.
Child care is open under certain restrictions, with priority placements for children of health care workers, first responders, and frontline workers.
Public transit is open under certain restrictions, and must be sanitized often and enforce 3 feet of space between passengers.
Overnight camps are not permitted. Day camps are open with restrictions, including maximum stable groups of 10 or fewer children.
For summer school, limited in-person, small group instruction and/or summer programming is allowed, with certain restrictions.
 Phase Level: 1, Phase Details Source information: https://govstatus.egov.com/reopening-oregon#phase1

Policy_Details: On 9/30 amended Safer at Home order issued by Scott Harris, State Health Officer (previous order was set to expire 10/2, only change is for HOSPITALS AND NURSING HOMES- Subject to restrictions, patients and residents will be allowed visits from one caregiver or one visitor at a time):
WHAT’S STAYING THE SAME:
EMPLOYERS
Businesses may open subject to sanitation and social-distancing guidelines
RETAIL STORES
May open subject to 50% occupancy rate, social-distancing and sanitation rules
CLOSE-CONTACT SERVICE PROVIDERS
Close-contact service providers (such as barber shops, hair salons, nail salons, tattoo services) may open
subject to social-distancing and sanitation rules and guidelines   Source information: https://governor.alabama.gov/assets/2020/09/GKI-0040-2020-Health-Order-Update-Nov-8-Horizontal-2.pdf,https://governor.alabama.gov/assets/2020/09/Safer-at-Home-Order-Final-9.29.2020.pdf

Policy_Details: There shall be no requirement that a face covering be worn: i. Within one's residence or automobile, unless transporting others for hire; ii. By a child twelve (12) years of age or younger; iii. By someone who has trouble breathing due to an underlying health condition or another bona fide medical or health-related reason for not wearing a face covering; ic. By someone who is incapacitated or otherwise unable to remove the cloth face covering without assistance; v. While eating or drinking; vi. While outdoors, unless the person cannot substantially maintain appropriate social distancing from others outside of the person's household; vii. While working under conditions where appropriate social distancing from others outside of the person's household is substantially maintained; viii. In situations in which wearing a face covering poses a safety or security risk; ix. While in a house of worship unless required by that house of worship, but wearing a face covering in such locations is strongly encouraged; x. While in a voting site for the purpose of voting or administering an election but wearing a face covering in such locations is strongly encouraged.   Source information: https://publications.tnsosfiles.com/pub/execorders/exec-orders-lee77.pdf

Policy_Details: """During Phase I, we can gradually start to reopen economic and social activity. This will be a deliberate process, and is flexible to adapt to the situation. Some communities may be able to reopen at a faster rate, while others may need to continue restrictions to keep the virus from spreading. During Phase I, we should limit our activity and interactions and continue to maintain social distancing and practice good hygiene to protect our neighbors and ourselves.

Citizens who feel sick should stay home!
Continue to practice good hygiene, including:
Washing hands with soap and water, or using hand sanitizer, especially after touching frequently used items or surfaces;
Avoiding touching your face;
Sneezing or coughing into a tissue, or the inside of your elbow; and
Disinfecting frequently used items and surfaces as much as possible.
Avoid socializing in groups that do not readily allow for appropriate physical distancing (receptions, trade shows, etc.). When in public (parks, outdoor recreation spaces, shopping malls, etc.), individuals should maximize physical distance from others.
Minimize travel to the extent possible."""   Source information: https://governor.mo.gov/sites/gov/files/media/pdf/2020/04/Economic-Reopening-Phase-1.pdf

- Large groups allowed such as festivals and sporting events. 
- Mass gatherings are permitted when following proper safety guidance and procedures.   Source information: https://ndresponse.gov/sites/www/files/documents/covid-19/ND%20Smart%20Restart/Additional%20Resources/NDSmartRestartPlan.pdf

Policy_Details: - All employees return to work with IDPH approved safety guidance; Employers are encouraged to provide accommodations for COVID-19-vulnerable employees.
- Retail: Open with capacity limits and IDPH approved safety guidance
- All barbershops, salons, spas and health and fitness clubs open with capacity limits and IDPH approved safety guidance   Source information: https://coronavirus.illinois.gov/s/restore-illinois-phase-4

Policy_Details: All non-essential businesses are allowed to have indoor operations but must have mitigative measures in place and can only operate at 25% capacity maximum   Source information: http://schsa.org/coronavirus/press/

Policy_Details: 21 counties approved to move to Phase 2: Adams, Asotin, Columbia, Cowlitz, Ferry, Garfield, Grant, Grays Harbor, Island, Jefferson, Lewis, Lincoln, Mason, Pacific, Pend Orielle, San Juan, Skamania, Spokane, Stevens, Wahkiakum and Whitman.

Phase 2: Business Activity Guidelines, dine in restaurants and taverns, in store retail, additional manufacturing operations, professional services, personal services, outdoor recreation, golf, construction, pet grooming, fitness and real estate opened subject to social distancing measures. Phase Level: 2, Phase Details Source information: https://coronavirus.wa.gov/news/seven-new-counties-approved-move-phase-2-gov-jay-inslees-safe-start-plan
Policy_Details: New York City enters phase 3.  Non-essential businesses such as personal care may reopn    Source information: https://forward.ny.gov/new-york-city-phase-three-industries

Policy_Details: Child care centers or home daycares may operate under restrictions
Child care provider ensure all people wash hands with soap and water upon arrival
Child care provider ensures staff and children are screened for symptoms of COVID-19 at beginning of day on arrival 
Business should maintain records of staff working hours for COVID-19 contact tracing
In event of confirmed case of COVID-19, provider shall close facility and consult local county health officer
Individuals dropping off or picking up children must stay 6 ft away from children 
Child care provider ensure that surfaces and areas are cleaned and sanitized after each use or at least twice a day
Child care centers and home daycares are required to follow all health guidelines from CDC and Wyoming Department of Health  Phase Level: 2, Phase Details Source information: https://covid19.wyo.gov/governors-orders

Policy_Details: Restaurants and bars/breweries offering sit-down meals may only operate with outdoor seating. If meals are not offered (at breweries) then they must be closed.   Source information: https://www.sandiegocounty.gov/content/sdc/hhsa/programs/phs/community_epidemiology/dc/2019-nCoV/reopening.html

Policy_Details: Main Street and retail businesses can become operational with reduced capacity and
where strict physical distancing protocols can be maintained.
Outdoor recreation can become operational if sites adhere to strict physical distancing
between groups and exercise frequent sanitation protocols if public facilities are open.
Organized youth activities can consider becoming operational if physical distancing
guidelines can be implemented. (Organized youth activities should avoid gathering in groups of more than 10 people in circumstances that do not readily allow for appropriate physical
distancing.) Phase Level: 1, Phase Details Source information: https://covid19.mt.gov/Portals/223/Documents/04-22-20%20Directive%20and%20Appx%20-%20Reopening%20Phase%20One.pdf?ver=2020-04-22-124954-977
Other measures and details for this policy include: religious gatherings exempt without clear social distance mandate

Policy_Details: County is approved to be exempt from the requirements of Governor Greg Abbot's Executive Order GA-29 signed on July 2 (face covering requirement in public spaces) given that the county has 20 or less active COVID-19 cases and the county judge has submitted an exemption.    Source information: https://tdem.texas.gov/ga29/, and
Policy_Details: Rural Reopening : all retail businesses open  Phase Level: 1, Phase Details Source information: https://www.maine.gov/covid19/restartingmaine

Policy_Details: Indoor unseated and seated events and entertainment: 50% capacity, or max 175 people
Outdoor unseated and seated events and entertainment: 50% capacity, or max 250 people   Source information: https://covid19.colorado.gov/covid-19-dial

Policy_Details: Executive Order 1466 by Governor Tate Reeves: Shelter in Place; all residents to stay home except for essential activities (restaurants, bars allowed to do takeout; personal care, other businesses, and most recreation/entertainment to be closed (parks closed, but walking trails at lakes/reservoirs open).  Ordered 4/1/2020, extended by another week by EO 1473 to end 4/27 but amended to allow for reopening of recreation outdoor spaces such as beaches, parks, lakes, etc. on limited basis.    Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1466.pdf, https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1473.pdf

Policy_Details: Masks required in a public setting and at long term care facilities   Source information: https://coronavirus.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/stay-healthy-order-stage3_2020oct27.pdf

Policy_Details: - Heightened exposure risk and transmission is controlled in these areas. 
- Cases are reported but contained by rapid testing and robust contact tracing. 
- Social distancing and precautions are needed (maintain 6-feet distancing, avoid shaking hands, work from home when possible, reconsider unnecessary travel, wear a
face mask). 
- Increased cleaning on high touch surfaces and cleanings on shared spaces should be routine.   Source information: https://ndresponse.gov/sites/www/files/documents/covid-19/ND%20Smart%20Restart/Additional%20Resources/NDSmartRestartPlan.pdf

Policy_Details: Executive Order by Governor Tate Reeves signed on 7/10, but only applying to Claiborne, Desoto, Grenada, Harrison, Hinds, Jackson, Jefferson, Madison, Quitman, Rnakin, Sunflower, Washington, and Wayne Counties. Amends Safe Return EO 1492/1496/1500/1505 for these counties. 
All businesses should be following relevant guidelines in these counties such as employee screening/reporting daily, social distancing, cleaning, and face coverings when 6 ft not possible.   Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1507.pdf

Auto Dealerships
Car Washes

Pet Grooming Services
Observatories & Support Facilities

Policy_Details: Governor amended executive order, statewide. An amended executive order, effective April 27, reopened on-site dining in restaurants and allowed them to continue takeout and delivery alcohol sales. Bars, nightclubs and "limited service restaurants" remain closed to on-site operations. Hospitals can resume some elective medical procedures as of May 1. Dental procedures can resume as of May 6. Beginning May 1, gyms and exercise facilities in most counties can reopen at 50% capacity. The state released guidelines for social distancing and worker and consumer protections. Close contact personal service businesses like barber shops and hair salons can reopen at 50% capacity in most counties beginning May 6. Tennessee's Economic Recovery Group released guidelines for business processes and employee and consumer protections.   Source information: https://publications.tnsosfiles.com/pub/execorders/exec-orders-lee29.pdf

Policy_Details: all restaurants and bars must close at 11:00 pm; tables spaced at least 6 ft apart; indoor tables limited to groups of 6; bar stools must be removed from the bar area (ordering, seating, congregating at bar area is prohibited); each party must have a reservation (even if made on-site) to ensure that the restaurant/bar has contact information for contact tracing    Source information: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2020-51.aspx

Policy_Details: Executive Order by Governor Tate Reeves signed on 7/10, but only applying to Claiborne, Desoto, Grenada, Harrison, Hinds, Jackson, Jefferson, Madison, Quitman, Rnakin, Sunflower, Washington, and Wayne Counties. Amends Safe Return EO 1492/1496/1500/1505 for these counties. 
All businesses should be following relevant guidelines in these counties such as employee screening/reporting daily, social distancing, cleaning, and face coverings when 6 ft not possible.
Retail Businesses should also in addition provide employees with face coverings (when they have contact with public, and these to be cleaned/replaced daily), customers must wear face coverings, hand sanitizer must be provided, 6 ft separation must be kept whenever possible, and sanitation of carts/baskets and high touch areas   Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1507.pdf

Policy_Details: Dakota, Hall, Hamilton and Merrick Counties: PHASE 1 All other counties: PHASE 2 Phase 1: Gatherings limited to 10 Personal Care: limited to 10 patrons, mask req'd for workers and patrons Restaurants: Dine-in OK, 50% capacity Bars: CLOSED Childcare: Limited to 15 kids per room/space Phase 2: All gatherings limited to 25 people. Food and Drink: Dine-in OK, 50% capacity, physical distancing Childcare: No more than 15 children per room/space Gyms/Fitness: Limited to 25 people or 50% capacity, physical distancing Personal Care: Limited to 25 people or 50% capacity, mask req'd for workers and patrons Phase Level: 1, Phase Details Source information: https://governor.nebraska.gov/press/gov-ricketts-announces-new-directed-health-measures-june

Policy_Details: Level Red: Severe Risk
More than 10% positivity rates.

Counties in this phase:
1. Alamosa
2. Denver
3. El Paso

5. Jefferson
6. Otero
7. Prowers
8. Washington
9. Summit

11. Clear Creek   Source information: https://covid19.colorado.gov/covid-19-dial

Policy_Details: All vulnerable Idahoans should continue to self-isolate. Gatherings, both public and private, of less than 10 people, where appropriate physical distancing and precautionary measures are observed can occur. Hair salons open if ability to meet business protocols. Indoor gyms and recreation facilities can open if ability to meet business protocols. Restaurant dining rooms can open once their plans have been submitted for approval by local public health districts. Nightclubs remain closed. Nightclubs should develop plans for reopening as a bar in Stage 3 with ability to meet business protocols and without close contact activities such as dancing. Bars remain closed. Bars should develop plans for reopening and ability to meet business protocols in order to open in stage 3. Large venues (e.g., movie theaters, and sporting venues) are closed. Phase Level: 2, Phase Details Source information: https://coronavirus.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/stay-healthy-order-stage2.pdf

Policy_Details: The stay at home order was originally extended until May 15th, but was not renewed by the Governor. The stay at home order has officially expired. People are allowed to: Go to the grocery, convenience or warehouse store Go to the pharmacy to pick up medications and other healthcare necessities Go to medical appointments (check with your doctor or provider first) Go to a restaurant for take-out, delivery or drive-thru Care for or support a friend or family member Take a walk, ride your bike, hike, jog and be in nature for exercise — just keep at least six feet between you and others. Walk your pets and take them to the veterinarian if necessary Help someone to get necessary supplies Receive deliveries from any business which delivers   Source information: https://gov.louisiana.gov/home/

Policy_Details: Governor Polis issued Executive Order D 2020 093 to amend Executive Orders D 2020 011, D 2020 029, D 2020 052, D 2020 084 due to COVID-19 -Suspend C.R.S. 44-3-103(38) defining premise as distinct and definite location and C.R.S. 44-3-301(3)(a) requiring separate geographical location for each licensed premises, for limited purpose of allowing two or more on-premise liquor licenses operating in accordance with Safer at Home, as amended, to obtain temporary approval from state & local licensing authorities to modify licensed premises to have communal outdoor dining area that is within 1,000 ft of their licensed premises -Liquor Enforcement Division takes action within 24 hours of submission for application of temporary modification of license -Temporarily suspend enforcement of statutory limitation prohibiting public consumption of alcohol beverages on any public right of way that has been authorized to allow such consumption by ordinance, resolution, or rule adopted by municipality, city and county, or county Phase Level: 2, Phase Details Source information: https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20093LiquorLicensingStatutes.pdf

Policy_Details: Executive Order by Governor Tate Reeves signed on 7/10, but only applying to Claiborne, Desoto, Grenada, Harrison, Hinds, Jackson, Jefferson, Madison, Quitman, Rnakin, Sunflower, Washington, and Wayne Counties. Amends Safe Return EO 1492/1496/1500/1505 for these counties. 
All businesses should be following relevant guidelines in these counties such as employee screening/reporting daily, social distancing, cleaning, and face coverings when 6 ft not possible.
Retail Businesses should also in addition provide employees with face coverings (when they have contact with public, and these to be cleaned/replaced daily), customers must wear face coverings, hand sanitizer must be provided, 6 ft separation must be kept whenever possible, and sanitation of carts/baskets and high touch areas   Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1507.pdf

Policy_Details   Source information: Email from Rachel Lancaster

Policy_Details: Pools: Limit the number of people in the facility at a time to ensure physical distancing. Limit use of indoor facilities. Direct the flow of patrons and employees through the facility to reduce person to person contact. Strictly monitor the use of the kiddie pool or other congregate areas.Thoroughly disinfect all surfaces and all equipment after each user. Employee face masks. Do not allow symptomatic persons entry. Use hand sanitizer or wash hands at the entrance to the facility upon arrival and departure. Provide soap, water, and alcohol-based hand rubs in multiple locations and routinely refill.

Gyms: Limit the number of people in the facility at a time to ensure physical distancing. Move activities outside if possible, and make sure there is optimal ventilation for inside activities. Direct the flow of patrons and staff through the facility to reduce person-to-person contact. Space exercise equipment at least six feet apart. Monitor employee health. Make hand sanitizer available at the entrance, in locker rooms, and throughout the facility. Shared equipment disinfected after each use.    Source information: https://rebound.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/stage3-protocols-outdoor-pools-splashparks-waterparks.pdf

Policy_Details: Accommodate staff at high risk for contracting the virus. Monitor staff health. Staff wear masks. Implement physical distancing measures like not mixing groups of students and staggering arrival/drop off times. Routine cleaning and sanitation of employee and student hands. Have children wash hands on arrival and departure.    Source information: https://rebound.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/stage1-protocols-childcare.pdf

Policy_Details: Gyms must limit occupancy of customers to 75% of the gym's maximum capacity. For all gyms and fitness center, high-touch areas must be sanitized at least once every two hours. If possible, create boundaries that establish one entrance for check in and another for exiting. All common areas must remain closed, with the exception of bathrooms/locker rooms. Do not allow gathering in lobby, break rooms, changing areas or throughout the facility. If the gym or fitness center serves high-risk populations, it is encouraged to set aside times and do so when fewer people are in the shop to maximize distancing and reduce risk of community transmission. Gyms and fitness centers must post signage at each entrance stating no customer with a fever or COVID-19 symptoms are allowed in. Limiting use of equipment by rearranging, taping, blocking or removing/deactivating equipment ensuring that clients are at a minimum of six (6) feet apart. Station hand sanitizer, disinfecting wipes, or similar disinfectant in visible and accessible locations throughout
the facility. Clients must sanitize their hands when entering arid exiting the gym and when moving between exercise equipment. If the gym provides towels for use by customers, such towels shall be stored in an airtight container. All linen hampers and trash containers shall be cleaned and disinfected daily, and all such containers must have a lid.   Source information: http://www.hattiesburgms.com/wp-content/uploads/exec_order_2020-22.pdf

Policy_Details: "During Phase I, we can gradually start to reopen economic and social activity. This will be a deliberate process, and is flexible to adapt to the situation. Some communities may be able to reopen at a faster rate, while others may need to continue restrictions to keep the virus from spreading. During Phase I, we should limit our activity and interactions and continue to maintain social distancing and practice good hygiene to protect our neighbors and ourselves. Citizens who feel sick should stay home! Continue to practice good hygiene, including: Washing hands with soap and water, or using hand sanitizer, especially after touching frequently used items or surfaces; Avoiding touching your face; Sneezing or coughing into a tissue, or the inside of your elbow; and Disinfecting frequently used items and surfaces as much as possible. Avoid socializing in groups that do not readily allow for appropriate physical distancing (receptions, trade shows, etc.). When in public (parks, outdoor recreation spaces, shopping malls, etc.), individuals should maximize physical distance from others. Minimize travel to the extent possible."   Source information: https://governor.mo.gov/sites/gov/files/media/pdf/2020/04/Economic-Reopening-Phase-1.pdf

Policy_Details: All businesses and employers are encouraged to adopt and/or take the following actions: Businesses should encourage customers to wear FACE COVERINGS. Continue to encourage TELEWORK, whenever possible and feasible with business operations. If possible, have employees RETURN TO WORK IN PHASES. CLOSE COMMON AREAS where personnel are likely to congregate and interact, or enforce strict social distancing protocols. Follow guidance from the NEVADA LABOR COMMISSIONER regarding sick leave policies. Strongly consider SPECIAL ACCOMMODATIONS for employees who are members of a vulnerable population. Consider encouraging employees to do a SELF-ASSESSMENT each day in order to check if they have any COVID-19 type symptoms (fever, cough or shortness of breath). Remind employees to STAY HOME WHEN SICK, use cough and sneeze etiquette, and practice hand hygiene. Frequently perform enhanced ENVIRONMENTAL CLEANING of commonly touched surfaces. Social Distancing & Sanitation Practices in Businesses - All businesses should consider proactive measures to help protect staff and customers, including but not limited to: • Implementing separate operating hours for the elderly and vulnerable customers. • Designating with signage, tape or by other means, six feet of spacing for employees, customers, clients or members to maintain appropriate distance. • Having hand sanitizer, and sanitizing products, readily available for employees and customers.   Source information: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Declaration-of-Emergency-Directive-018.Phase-1-Reopening.5-7-20-1.pdf

Policy_Details: HEALTH AND FITNESS:
• Capacity limit of no more than 50% occupancy
• Group fitness classes of up to 50 people with at least 6 ft. social distancing
between individuals permitted; multiple groups permitted given facilities
have space to appropriately social distance and can limit interaction
between groups
• Workout stations and equipment should be 6 ft. apart without barriers or 3
ft. apart with impermeable barriers in between
• For open gym spaces, have 1 employee per every 4,000 sq. ft. to monitor
social distancing and sanitize equipment between use
• Sanitize equipment before and after each individual use and sanitize locker
rooms and showers at least every hour
• Keep ancillary accommodations (e.g., saunas, hot tubs, steam rooms)
closed, though childcare areas are permitted to reopen in line with DHFS
childcare guidelines
• Members should wear face covering over their nose and mouth whenever
not exercising 

INDOOR/OUTDOOR RECREATION:
• Reopening select indoor recreation facilities (e.g., bowling alleys, skating
rinks); indoor playgrounds and trampoline parks should remain closed
• Indoor recreation to operate at lesser of 50 customers or 50% of
facility capacity
• Outdoor recreation allowing group sizes of up to 50, and permitting
multiple groups given facilities have space to appropriately social distance
and can limit interaction between groups
• Activity stations should be spaced at least 6 ft. apart or limited in number
to ensure social distancing
• Shared equipment should be disinfected before and after each use
• Clubhouses and other communal gathering places allowed to reopen
• Concessions permitted with restrictions 

YOUTH AND RECREATIONAL SPORTS
• Competitive gameplay and tournaments permitted
• Capacity limit of no more than 50% facility capacity, 20% seating capacity
for spectators
• Group sizes limited to 50 participants total (including athletes, coaches,
and referees); with multiple groups permitted during practice and
competitive games given venues have space to appropriately social
distance and can limit interaction between group
• Concessions permitted with restrictions   Source information: https://dceocovid19resources.com/assets/Restore-Illinois/businessguidelines4/phase4overview.pdf

Policy_Details: "Restaurants and bars must:
Ensure tables are spaced at least six (6) feet apart so that at least six (6) feet between parties is maintained, including when customers approach or leave tables
Require all employees to wear cloth face or disposable coverings (provided by the employer)
End all on-site consumption of food and drinks by 10pm      Personal care services (salons, barber shops, massage, etc.) must:
Make appointments with pre-appointment health check
Maintain a customer log
Maintain Six feet physical distancing between clients
Remove all magazines, newspapers, snacks and beverages from waiting areas
Require face coverings by employees and clients (depending on the services provided)     Gyms/ fitness must:
Limit maximum number of customers accordingly
Enforce physical distancing & sanitation"   Source information: https://govstatus.egov.com/reopening-oregon#phase1

Policy_Details: This is NOT an SIP/SAH. It is a Public Health Disaster Emergency Proclamation "Today, [5/13/20] Governor Reynolds signed a new proclamation continuing the Public Health Disaster Emergency. The proclamation permits salons, barbershops, and massage and tattoo establishments to reopen throughout Iowa in a limited fashion with appropriate public health measures in place. It also permits restaurants (but not bars), fitness centers, libraries, and race tracks to reopen in the 22 counties where they have remained closed. These changes are effective at 5:00 a.m. on Friday, May 15. The proclamation continues the other ongoing closures and public health measures, including the prohibition on social, community, recreational, leisure, and sporting gatherings and events of more than 10 people, until 11:59 p.m. on May 27, 2020."   Source information: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.05.13.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery

Policy_Details: "Restaurants and bars must:
Ensure tables are spaced at least six (6) feet apart so that at least six (6) feet between parties is maintained, including when customers approach or leave tables
Require all employees to wear cloth face or disposable coverings (provided by the employer)
End all on-site consumption of food and drinks by 10pm      Personal care services (salons, barber shops, massage, etc.) must:
Make appointments with pre-appointment health check
Maintain a customer log
Maintain Six feet physical distancing between clients
Remove all magazines, newspapers, snacks and beverages from waiting areas
Require face coverings by employees and clients (depending on the services provided)     Gyms/ fitness must:
Limit maximum number of customers accordingly
Enforce physical distancing & sanitation"   Source information: https://govstatus.egov.com/reopening-oregon#phase1

Policy_Details: Currently open: Grocery stores, pharmacies, banks and credit unions, and gas stations are all open.
Restaurants are open for take-out service only.
Stand alone retail operations are open provided they meet required safety and physical distancing guidelines. Indoor and outdoor malls are closed.
Local outdoor recreation activities are open, including many state parks.
Non-emergency medical care, dentist offices and veterinary care are open and operating, provided they meet required safety guidelines.
Local cultural, civic and faith gatherings are allowed for up to 25 people provided physical distancing can be in place.
Local social gatherings over 10 people are prohibited and those under 10 people must use physical distancing.
Personal care services such as salons and barbers, as well as gyms, are closed.
Child care is open under certain restrictions, with priority placements for children of health care workers, first responders, and frontline workers.
Public transit is open under certain restrictions, and must be sanitized often and enforce 3 feet of space between passengers.
Overnight camps are not permitted. Day camps are open with restrictions, including maximum stable groups of 10 or fewer children.
For summer school, limited in-person, small group instruction and/or summer programming is allowed, with certain restrictions.
 Phase Level: 1, Phase Details Source information: https://govstatus.egov.com/reopening-oregon#phase1

Policy_Details: New Mexico's stay at home restrictions were modified on April 30, with an extension of the state's stay-at-home order in place until May 15.
New Mexicans must remain home except for outings essential for health, safety and welfare, especially elderly and vulnerable individuals. If you must leave home, gatherings of more than five people remain prohibited and 6 feet of physical distance from others must be maintained.
High-intensity contact services that must remain closed include massage and tattoo parlors.   Source information: https://cv.nmhealth.org/2020/05/13/stay-at-home-order-extended/

Policy_Details: "All businesses and employers are encouraged to adopt and/or take the following
actions:
Businesses should encourage customers to wear FACE COVERINGS.
Continue to encourage TELEWORK, whenever possible and feasible with business operations.
If possible, have employees RETURN TO WORK IN PHASES.
CLOSE COMMON AREAS where personnel are likely to congregate and interact, or enforce strict social
distancing protocols.
Follow guidance from the NEVADA LABOR COMMISSIONER regarding sick leave policies.
Strongly consider SPECIAL ACCOMMODATIONS for employees who are members of a vulnerable
population.
Consider encouraging employees to do a SELF-ASSESSMENT each day in order to check if they have
any COVID-19 type symptoms (fever, cough or shortness of breath).
Remind employees to STAY HOME WHEN SICK, use cough and sneeze etiquette, and practice hand
hygiene.
Frequently perform enhanced ENVIRONMENTAL CLEANING of commonly touched surfaces.
Social Distancing & Sanitation Practices in Businesses - All businesses should consider proactive
measures to help protect staff and customers, including but not limited to:
• Implementing separate operating hours for the elderly and vulnerable customers.
• Designating with signage, tape or by other means, six feet of spacing for employees, customers,
clients or members to maintain appropriate distance.
• Having hand sanitizer, and sanitizing products, readily available for employees and customers."   Source information: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Declaration-of-Emergency-Directive-018.Phase-1-Reopening.5-7-20-1.pdf

Policy_Details: "Restaurants and bars must:
Ensure tables are spaced at least six (6) feet apart so that at least six (6) feet between parties is maintained, including when customers approach or leave tables
Require all employees to wear cloth face or disposable coverings (provided by the employer)
End all on-site consumption of food and drinks by 10pm      Personal care services (salons, barber shops, massage, etc.) must:
Make appointments with pre-appointment health check
Maintain a customer log
Maintain Six feet physical distancing between clients
Remove all magazines, newspapers, snacks and beverages from waiting areas
Require face coverings by employees and clients (depending on the services provided)     Gyms/ fitness must:
Limit maximum number of customers accordingly
Enforce physical distancing & sanitation"   Source information: https://govstatus.egov.com/reopening-oregon#phase1

Policy_Details: Currently open: Grocery stores, pharmacies, banks and credit unions, and gas stations are all open.
Restaurants are open for take-out service only.
Stand alone retail operations are open provided they meet required safety and physical distancing guidelines. Indoor and outdoor malls are closed.
Local outdoor recreation activities are open, including many state parks.
Non-emergency medical care, dentist offices and veterinary care are open and operating, provided they meet required safety guidelines.
Local cultural, civic and faith gatherings are allowed for up to 25 people provided physical distancing can be in place.
Local social gatherings over 10 people are prohibited and those under 10 people must use physical distancing.
Personal care services such as salons and barbers, as well as gyms, are closed.
Child care is open under certain restrictions, with priority placements for children of health care workers, first responders, and frontline workers.
Public transit is open under certain restrictions, and must be sanitized often and enforce 3 feet of space between passengers.
Overnight camps are not permitted. Day camps are open with restrictions, including maximum stable groups of 10 or fewer children.
For summer school, limited in-person, small group instruction and/or summer programming is allowed, with certain restrictions.
 Phase Level: 1, Phase Details Source information: https://govstatus.egov.com/reopening-oregon#phase1

Policy_Details: *Georgia does not have phase numbers associated with restrictions/orders. Governor Brian Kemp signed Executive Order on August 15th to extend/amend the Empowering a Healthy Georgia order for another two weeks since the most recent order from the beginning of August that expired August 15th . The order is comprehensive and outlines the restrictions/reopening of different business types as well as limits on gatherings and requirements for businesses. Local governments in Georgia previously could not mandate face coverings, as noted in the previous order, but now are able to on a limited basis require them on government property when threshold met in a county (100+ cases per 100,000 people in previous 14 days). Face coverings are otherwise strongly encouraged.   Source information: https://gov.georgia.gov/executive-action/executive-orders/2020-executive-orders

Gatherings limited to 10 indoors (with social distancing of 6 feet, or with face coverings required when 6 feet is not possible) and 20 outdoors (with social distancing 6 feet, or with face coverings required when 6 ft is not possible).

Policy_Details: Phase 2: Gov. Beshear announced the second phase of reopening the commonwealth’s economy
All businesses should follow the 10 rules of staying healthy at work as well as industry-specific guidance, which will be issued as soon as possible. The new tentative dates for reopening are: May 9 - houses of worship open to 33%
May 22 – Restaurants, with limited 33% capacity and outdoor seating, May 25 - reopening of personal care establishments 
June 1 – Movie theaters, fitness centers June 10 - houses of worship to 50%
June 11 – Campgrounds, public and private
June 15 – Child care, with reduced capacity; and potentially low-touch and outdoor youth sports
The Governor added that Phase 3 is coming July 1 with bars, with limitations, and gatherings up to 50 people allowed. Phase Level: 2, Phase Details Source information: https://kentucky.gov/Pages/Activity-stream.aspx?n=GovernorBeshear&prId=156, https://govstatus.egov.com/ky-healthy-at-work

Local cultural, civic and faith gatherings are allowed for up to 25 people provided physical distancing can be in place.

Policy_Details: - Most normal activity can resume, with standard precautions and awareness of health
guidelines such as routine hand washing, stay home when sick, cover your cough, education, stockpiling, planning, routine health alerts, etc. 
- Monitoring for illness and outbreaks will continue. 
- Those found to be ill will be asked to self-isolate and contacts will be asked to remain at home.   Source information: https://ndresponse.gov/sites/www/files/documents/covid-19/ND%20Smart%20Restart/Additional%20Resources/NDSmartRestartPlan.pdf

Policy_Details: "All businesses and employers are encouraged to adopt and/or take the following
actions:
Businesses should encourage customers to wear FACE COVERINGS.
Continue to encourage TELEWORK, whenever possible and feasible with business operations.
If possible, have employees RETURN TO WORK IN PHASES.
CLOSE COMMON AREAS where personnel are likely to congregate and interact, or enforce strict social
distancing protocols.
Follow guidance from the NEVADA LABOR COMMISSIONER regarding sick leave policies.
Strongly consider SPECIAL ACCOMMODATIONS for employees who are members of a vulnerable
population.
Consider encouraging employees to do a SELF-ASSESSMENT each day in order to check if they have
any COVID-19 type symptoms (fever, cough or shortness of breath).
Remind employees to STAY HOME WHEN SICK, use cough and sneeze etiquette, and practice hand
hygiene.
Frequently perform enhanced ENVIRONMENTAL CLEANING of commonly touched surfaces.
Social Distancing & Sanitation Practices in Businesses - All businesses should consider proactive
measures to help protect staff and customers, including but not limited to:
• Implementing separate operating hours for the elderly and vulnerable customers.
• Designating with signage, tape or by other means, six feet of spacing for employees, customers,
clients or members to maintain appropriate distance.
• Having hand sanitizer, and sanitizing products, readily available for employees and customers."   Source information: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Declaration-of-Emergency-Directive-018.Phase-1-Reopening.5-7-20-1.pdf

Policy_Details: Six foot physical distancing requirements for staff, volunteers, and worshippers for services and activities. Offer more protected areas for more vulnerable people and offer them separate areas of entry and exit. Limit the number of people in the service. Recommend worshippers refrain from hugging, handshaking, and other physical contact. Regularly clean and disinfect the facility. Encourage anyone who enters the place of worship to wash hands or use hand sanitizer prior to entry. Ask all staff, volunteers, and worshippers to self monitor for fever or symptoms of COVID-19. Ensure religious leaders always wash their hands or use a hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol prior to conducting the service and any close contact or interaction with others. Consider whether to modify specific religious rites, rituals, and services, consulting with local public health officials as needed. Consider online collections or donations.   Source information: https://rebound.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/stage1-protocols-worship.pdf
Policy_Details: Gyms, fitness centers, playgrounds, etc. may only operate outdoors   Source information: http://schsa.org/coronavirus/press/

Policy_Details: - Heightened exposure risk and transmission is controlled in these areas. 
- Cases are reported but contained by rapid testing and robust contact tracing. 
- Social distancing and precautions are needed (maintain 6-feet distancing, avoid shaking hands, work from home when possible, reconsider unnecessary travel, wear a

Policy_Details: *note: "phases" are not really used to describe MS reopening.  Safe Return Order: Executive Order 1492 by Governor Reeves: Gatherings: non-socially distant (within 6 ft) gatherings to be no more than 20 people indoors or 50 people in an outdoor space; socially distant gatherings (w/ 6 ft minimum distance) no more than 50 people indoors or 100 people outdoors. All businesses/nonprofits now allowed to reopen or remain open w/ limitations: (most already allowed to reopen given restrictions in previous orders) but now Executive Order 1478 amended to allow bars that do not serve food to also reopen given limitations of that order (50% capacity, employee screening & PPE, social distancing between parties, etc.) and amended to allow live music in restaurants and bars given 12 ft distance between performers and customers. Healthcare: emergency and elective procedures allowed to continue to be performed (facilities must reserve 25% of capacity for COVID-19 patients) Outdoor Recreational Activities: (had already been widely reopened w/restrictions in previous orders 1473, 1486, 1491, 1480, 1487, no significant changes) Indoor amusement venues (bowling alleys, rollerskating rinks, arcades, playgrounds, etc.): allowed to reopen 50% capacity, group gatherings limited to 20 customers Reception halls and conference centers allowed to reopen to 25% capacity w/social distancing of tables and max 6 to a table Schools: may reopen for in-person instruction (summer school, special ed, tutoring, etc.) State Courts are to be open. All businesses were allowed to reopen, including bars and movie theaters, capacity limits and additional guidelines.  Phase Level: 3, Phase Details Source information: https://governorreeves.ms.gov/wp-content/uploads/Executive-Order-1492-Safer-Return.pdf

Policy_Details: Executive Order by Governor Tate Reeves signed on 7/10, but only applying to Claiborne, Desoto, Grenada, Harrison, Hinds, Jackson, Jefferson, Madison, Quitman, Rnakin, Sunflower, Washington, and Wayne Counties. Amends Safe Return EO 1492/1496/1500/1505 for these counties. 
All businesses should be following relevant guidelines in these counties such as employee screening/reporting daily, social distancing, cleaning, and face coverings when 6 ft not possible.
Retail Businesses should also in addition provide employees with face coverings (when they have contact with public, and these to be cleaned/replaced daily), customers must wear face coverings, hand sanitizer must be provided, 6 ft separation must be kept whenever possible, and sanitation of carts/baskets and high touch areas   Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1507.pdf

Policy_Details: """During Phase I, we can gradually start to reopen economic and social activity. This will be a deliberate process, and is flexible to adapt to the situation. Some communities may be able to reopen at a faster rate, while others may need to continue restrictions to keep the virus from spreading. During Phase I, we should limit our activity and interactions and continue to maintain social distancing and practice good hygiene to protect our neighbors and ourselves.

Citizens who feel sick should stay home!
Continue to practice good hygiene, including:
Washing hands with soap and water, or using hand sanitizer, especially after touching frequently used items or surfaces;
Avoiding touching your face;
Sneezing or coughing into a tissue, or the inside of your elbow; and
Disinfecting frequently used items and surfaces as much as possible.
Avoid socializing in groups that do not readily allow for appropriate physical distancing (receptions, trade shows, etc.). When in public (parks, outdoor recreation spaces, shopping malls, etc.), individuals should maximize physical distance from others.
Minimize travel to the extent possible."""   Source information: https://governor.mo.gov/sites/gov/files/media/pdf/2020/04/Economic-Reopening-Phase-1.pdf

Policy_Details: Phase 2 of the "Ad Astra" plan. Phase Level: 2, Phase Details: Mass gatherings of more than 15 individuals will be prohibited; All businesses and activities slated to open during Phase 2 will be allowed, with the exception of bars, night clubs and swimming pools. These will be moved to Phase 3; Businesses and activities that will be allowed to open in Phase 2 include: Recreational organized sports facilities, tournaments and practices will be allowed to begin on Friday, May 22, and must adhere to social distancing requirements and follow Parks and Recs guidelines, which can be found on covid.ks.gov; Community Centers will be allowed to open, except for indoor and outdoor swimming pools; Indoor leisure spaces such as arcades, trampoline parks, theaters, museums and bowling allies will be allowed to open on May 22; State-owned-and-operated casinos will be allowed to open once their re-opening plan has been approved by the Kansas Department of Health and Environment; In-person group exercise classes will be allowed to begin with groups of no more than 15 at a time. Locker rooms remain closed except for restroom facilities; Everything opened in Phase 1 and Phase 1.5 remains open pursuant to the restrictions outlined in Executive Order 20-34. Source information: https://governor.kansas.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/EO-20-34-Implementing-Phase-2-Executed.pdf

Policy_Details: Face Coverings Directive Issued July 18, 2020 by Department of Health- The Secretary of Health requires every person in Arkansas to wear a face covering completely over the mouth and nose in all indoor environments, excluding private residences, where they are exposed to non-household members and distancing of six (6) feet or more cannot be assured and in all outdoor settings, excluding private residences, where there is exposure to non-household members, unless there exists ample space of six (6) feet or more to practice physical distancing.  The following shall be exempt from wearing a face covering a. Persons younger than 10 years of age (This requirement shall not supersede any decision by the Secretary of Education, public school district, or private school to require masks for children younger than 10 years of age while attending school); b. Persons with a medical condition or disability that prevents wearing a face covering; c. Persons performing job duties where a six feet distance is not achievable, but a mask is inhibitory to the ability to safely and effectively perform the job duty; d. Persons participating in athletic activities where a six feet distance is not achievable, but a mask is inhibitory to the activity or active exercise; e. Persons consuming food or drink; f. Persons driving alone or with passengers from the driver’s household; g. Persons receiving services that require access to the face for security, surveillance, or other purposes may temporarily remove a face covering while receiving those services; h. Persons voting, assisting voters, serving as poll watchers, or actively performing election administration duties; however, face coverings are strongly encouraged; i. Persons engaged in religious worship activities; however, face coverings are strongly encouraged; j. Persons giving a speech or performance for broadcast or to an audience; however, those persons shall safely distance from nearby individuals; k. Persons in counties where the Department of Health has certified that risk of community transmission of COVID-19 is low. To be considered low risk, the county must not have a newly identified case of COVID-19 for twenty-eight (28) consecutive days, assuming there has been adequate testing in the county   Source information: https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/face_covering_directive.pdf

Policy_Details: "All businesses and employers are encouraged to adopt and/or take the following
actions:
Businesses should encourage customers to wear FACE COVERINGS.
Continue to encourage TELEWORK, whenever possible and feasible with business operations.
If possible, have employees RETURN TO WORK IN PHASES.
CLOSE COMMON AREAS where personnel are likely to congregate and interact, or enforce strict social
distancing protocols.
Follow guidance from the NEVADA LABOR COMMISSIONER regarding sick leave policies.
Strongly consider SPECIAL ACCOMMODATIONS for employees who are members of a vulnerable
population.
Consider encouraging employees to do a SELF-ASSESSMENT each day in order to check if they have
any COVID-19 type symptoms (fever, cough or shortness of breath).
Remind employees to STAY HOME WHEN SICK, use cough and sneeze etiquette, and practice hand
hygiene.
Frequently perform enhanced ENVIRONMENTAL CLEANING of commonly touched surfaces.
Social Distancing & Sanitation Practices in Businesses - All businesses should consider proactive
measures to help protect staff and customers, including but not limited to:
• Implementing separate operating hours for the elderly and vulnerable customers.
• Designating with signage, tape or by other means, six feet of spacing for employees, customers,
clients or members to maintain appropriate distance.
• Having hand sanitizer, and sanitizing products, readily available for employees and customers."   Source information: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Declaration-of-Emergency-Directive-018.Phase-1-Reopening.5-7-20-1.pdf

Policy_Details: Governor Brian Kemp signed Executive Order on August 15th to extend/amend the Empowering a Healthy Georgia order for another two weeks since the most recent order from the beginning of August that expired August 15th . Local governments in Georgia previously could not mandate face coverings, as noted in the previous order, but now are able to on a limited basis require them on government property when threshold met in a county (100+ cases per 100,000 people in previous 14 days).  These Local Option Face Covering Requirements should not be applied when eating/drinking, people who are unable to put on and take off a mask without assistance, those with a religious objection, medical reason.  There should not be any fines or penalties against businesses or other entities and there should not be any fines in excess of 50 dollars per person per offense.  The order cannot be enforced at polling places, private property without consent of owner or occupant, or residential property.
Face coverings are otherwise strongly encouraged.   Source information: https://gov.georgia.gov/executive-action/executive-orders/2020-executive-orders

Policy_Details: Governor Roy Cooper Executive Order No. 147 amended Executive Order No. 141 to require face coverings. requires people, with some exceptions, to wear face coverings in public when social distancing is not possible- to be worn by workers at restaurants when within 6 ft of others and also require customers to wear them when not at their table employees, in manufacturing sites, construction sites, farming settings, and specifically surgical masks in meat packing plants, in retail stores when within/may be within 6 ft of others, also require customers to wear them unless an exception applies.  state government offices and agencies must also have all employees wearing face coverings when within 6 ft or may be within 6 ft of another person., by all staff and children over the age of 11 at childcare facilities, day camps, and overnight camps when within 6 ft or may be within 6 ft of others by all staff and children over the age of 11 at childcare facilities, day camps, and overnight camps when within 6 ft or may be within 6 ft of others, by employees and customers at personal care businesses when within or may be within 6 ft of others, except when treatment is being applied to face   Source information: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO147-Phase-2-Extension.pdf

Policy_Details: This is NOT an SIP/SAH.  It is a Public Health Disaster Emergency Proclamation

"Today, [5/13/20] Governor Reynolds signed a new proclamation continuing the Public Health Disaster Emergency. The proclamation permits salons, barbershops, and massage and tattoo establishments to reopen throughout Iowa in a limited fashion with appropriate public health measures in place. It also permits restaurants (but not bars), fitness centers, libraries, and race tracks to reopen in the 22 counties where they have remained closed. These changes are effective at 5:00 a.m. on Friday, May 15.

The proclamation continues the other ongoing closures and public health measures, including the prohibition on social, community, recreational, leisure, and sporting gatherings and events of more than 10 people, until 11:59 p.m. on May 27, 2020."    Source information: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.05.13.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery

check.   Source information: https://covid-response-moa-muniorg.hub.arcgis.com/pages/emergency-orders

face mask).

Source information: https://sjbpublichealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/20-35-Safer-at-Home-Dial.SecondAmended.100820.pdf

Policy_Details: - Persons must wear a mask in the common areas of apartments, condominiums and cooperatives.
-Businesses, office buildings, and other establishments open to members of the public shall post signage on their exterior doors stating that a person may not enter unless the person is wearing a mask. (Allowed to eject individuals who do not where masks)
-Employers shall provide masks to their employees.
-Persons leaving their residences shall wear a mask when they are likely to come into contact with another person; especially in public transit   Source information: https://coronavirus.dc.gov/maskorder

Policy_Details: Gov Stitt announced Phase 3 of OK plan to begin on June 1. 
Changes include: Summer camps (church and school) can open
Businesses can resume unrestricted staffing at their worksites by observing proper social distancing protocols.
Businesses operating by appointment only may begin operating by appointment and
walk-in at their discretion.
Limited visitation at hospitals may be reinstated, but visitation at long-term care facilities remains suspended, except for end-of-life situations.
Those 65 and older and vulnerable populations are encouraged to stay home.   Source information: https://www.tulsaworld.com/news/oklahoma-to-begin-phase-3-of-reopening-monday-after-covid-19-data-shows-promising-downward/article_542617ce-c9e8-5825-bfdd-db6796999793.html, https://www.okcommerce.gov/wp-content/uploads/Open-Up-and-Recover-Safely-Plan.pdf

Policy_Details: All bars, nightclubs, music venues, indoor entertainment venues and places of amusement (including but not limited to: bowling alleys, laser tag, ax throwing bars, escape rooms, movie theaters) shall close at 1 a.m. All dance hall permits are suspended.   Source information: http://www.hattiesburgms.com/wp-content/uploads/exec_order_2020-22.pdf

Policy_Details: Executive Order by Governor Tate Reeves signed on 7/10, but only applying to Claiborne, Desoto, Grenada, Harrison, Hinds, Jackson, Jefferson, Madison, Quitman, Rnakin, Sunflower, Washington, and Wayne Counties. Amends Safe Return EO 1492/1496/1500/1505 for these counties.

Policy_Details: If on June 17, a nursing home has no active COVID-19 cases for at least the past consecutive 14 days, visitation will be allowed to resume, with an appointment  Phase Level: 2, Phase Details Source information: https://governor.wv.gov/News/press-releases/2020/Pages/COVID-19-UPDATE-Gov.-Justice-announces-nursing-home-visitation,-graduation-ceremonies-to-be-allowed-with-limitations.aspx

Policy_Details: Governor Carney announced Phase 2 of Delaware's reopening will begin June 15, 2020
INDIVIDUAL GUIDELINES
-Cloth coverings must be worn
-Non-household members must maximize social distancing
-All individuals in public (parks, outdoor recreation areas, shopping, etc) must social distance
-Indoor gathering limit: 50 people but social distance from non-household members
-Places operating at 30% occupancy under Phase 1 can move to 60% occupancy 
-Exercise facilities and personal care services (hair, tanning, tattoo, massage, nail, brow, spas) to remain at 30% occupancy
-Fully unenclosed outdoor gatherings of up to 250 people are permitted
-Leisure travel should be avoided but may resume under general guidance
-All vulnerable individuals should continue to shelter in place
BUSINESS GUIDELINES
-Common areas where people can congregate must remain closed
-Employees/customers have responsibility to self-quarantine if they think they may be sick
-Teleworking is encouraged
-All surfaces touched by customers must be disinfected by EPA-approved disinfectant every 15 minutes to 2 hours 
-Employees required to go to work should perform daily health work 
-All employees must wash hands throughout the day and use hand sanitizer and social distance from other employees
-Businesses must make hand sanitizer available to employees and patrons (hand sanitizer must be 60% ethanol and 70% isopropanol 
-Downtime should be given between shifts and after closing for cleaning 
-Employees must post signs about how to stop spread of COVID-19, hand hygiene, and wear a face covering  Phase Level: 2, Phase Details Source information: https://governor.delaware.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/24/2020/06/Delaware-Economic-Reopening-PHASE-2.pdf
Policy_Details: phase 2 begins in Cass County Phase Level: 2, Phase Details Source information: https://backontrack.in.gov/files/BackOnTrack-IN_WhatsOpen-Closed-stage2.pdf

Policy_Details: Any organization conducting youth sports must submit a Sport Activity Plan, and the Health Department must approve the plan before practices or events can occur. Policy_Details: Restaurants and bars must: Ensure tables are spaced at least six (6) feet apart so that at least six (6) feet between parties is maintained, including when customers approach or leave tables Require all employees to wear cloth face or disposable coverings (provided by the employer) End all on-site consumption of food and drinks by 10pm Personal care services (salons, barber shops, massage, etc.) must: Make appointments with pre-appointment health check Maintain a customer log Maintain Six feet physical distancing between clients Remove all magazines, newspapers, snacks and beverages from waiting areas Require face coverings by employees and clients (depending on the services provided) Gyms/ fitness must: Limit maximum number of customers accordingly Enforce physical distancing & sanitation   Source information: https://govstatus.egov.com/reopening-oregon#phase1

Source information: https://cv.nmhealth.org/public-health-orders-and-executive-orders/red-to-green/

Policy_Details: Governor Northam issued amended Executive Order 65 easing certain temporary restrictions of businesses Restaurants, dining establishments, food courts, breweries, microbreweries, distilleries, wineries, and tasting rooms may operate delivery, take out, indoor/outdoor dining, and beverage services in compliance with guidelines Occupancy may not exceed 50% All parties must be limited to 50 patrons or less Tables at which dining parties are seated must be positioned 6 ft apart No self service of food (except beverages) and including condiments Bar seats must be closed to patrons except for through traffic Employees must wear face coverings at all times Cleaning and disinfection of frequently contacted surfaces must be conducted every 60 minutes If businesses cannot adhere to these guidelines, they must close Phase Level: 2, Phase Details Source information: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-65-and-Order-Of-Public-Health-Emergency-Six---AMENDED---Phase-Two-Easing-of-Certain-Temporary-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf

Policy_Details: o Restaurants, bars, breweries, distilleries, and casinos can become operational on or after
May 4, 2020 under strict physical distancing and reduced capacity protocols in
accordance with State guidelines.
 These businesses will be required to close their doors and have all patrons out by
11:30 p.m. Breweries and distilleries shall follow existing laws on closing time.
 The expansions for delivery and takeout services, as provided both in the March
24 and March 26 Directives, are extended through the end of the emergency.
 In addition, restaurants, bars, breweries, distilleries, and casinos that reopen
must adhere to the general and specific guidelines provided in Appendix A,
attached. Phase Level: 1, Phase Details Source information: https://covid19.mt.gov/Portals/223/Documents/04-22-20%20Directive%20and%20Appx%20-%20Reopening%20Phase%20One.pdf?ver=2020-04-22-124954-977

Policy_Details: - Places of worship are encouraged to continue providing virtual services.

- Places of worship may operate with expanded capacity limits. In no event shall attendance at any service exceed 50% of the capacity of the facility or space where the service is occurring as set forth in its Certificate of Occupancy, or 100 persons, whichever is fewer. Groups of persons attending together shall not exceed 10 persons. Each group must be seated at least 6 feet from each other group.

- Places of worship that choose to operate on this limited basis must clean the facility between services and are encouraged to take reservations and assign seats to conform to this requirement and so as to facilitate contact tracing.

- Singing, choirs, all physical touching of others, and the passing or sharing of items pose particular dangers and are discouraged so as to prevent the spread of COVID-19.   Source information: https://coronavirus.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/coronavirus/page_content/attachments/COVID-19_DC_Health_%20Guidance_for_Places_of_Worship_08202020.pdf

Policy_Details: On May 22, the state entered phase 2, which allows restaurants to open dine-in services and personal care businesses such as salons and barbershops at 50 percent capacity. Gatherings are limited to 10 people indoors and 25 people outdoors. Gyms, bars, nightclubs and indoor entertainment such as movie theaters will remain closed. The phase will last until at least June 26. Policy_Details: Governor lifted two executive orders, statewide. McMaster lifted the order on May 4. Restaurants are now able to resume outdoor customer dining services in line with sanitation and social distancing guidelines. As of May 11, restaurants can choose to reopen for limited dine-in services if they follow state guidelines, including capping indoor occupancy at 50%. Close contact service providers, fitness and exercise centers, commercial gyms — including group exercise classes — and public or commercial pools can open in a limited capacity on May 18. The state has issued general guidelines for close contact service providers, as well as specific guidelines for cosmetology establishments, pools and fitness centers. McMaster lifted restrictions on boating statewide, effective May 8. Daycare facilities are allowed to open.   Source information: https://governor.sc.gov/news/2020-05/gov-henry-mcmaster-lift-work-or-home-order-may-4th

Policy_Details: Cooper signed an executive order modifying the stay-at-home order and transitioning the state into Phase 1 of easing restrictions, effective 5:00 p.m. on May 8. The order will last until at least May 22.
The modified order removes the distinction between essential and nonessential businesses. Retail businesses may operate at 50% capacity and must implement health and safety measures for workers and customers. Cloth face coverings are recommended for workers, and teleworking is encouraged whenever possible.
In Phase 1, bars, entertainment venues will stay closed. Phase Level: 1, Phase Details Source information: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO121-Stay-at-Home-Order-3.pdf

Policy_Details: overnight youth summer camps open at 75% bed capacity ; residential college programming limited to 8 weeks, 50 participants  ; overnight camps & residential college programs may operate in groups greater than 25 as long as physical distancing is ensured ; non-essential visits from family & friends prohibited ; cuationary drop-off procedures (i.e. curbside drop-off, no overnight accomodations for families,  1 family member/camper, bus service for out-of-state campers to reduce cross-state travel) ; out-of-state staff & campers must complete quarantine of (i) 14 days at home or camp or (ii) 7 days at home or camp with negative test result   Source information: https://governor.vermont.gov/press-release/governor-phil-scott-announces-opening-additional-business-operations-increased-social

Policy_Details: To prepare businesses and employers to implement new and updated safety guidelines in Phase 4, the State of Illinois has developed this business toolkit complete with signage, posters, and other resources to ensure business and activities are conducted in accordance with the latest public health recommendations. Policy_Details: - Curbside pickup, takeout, and delivery options preferable.
- Dine-in service limited to 50% of normal seating capacity with extreme caution.
- Pre-screen and monitor employees for symptoms.
- No more than 10 people per table.
- Masks and social distancing required.   Source information: https://ndresponse.gov/sites/www/files/documents/covid-19/ND%20Smart%20Restart/Additional%20Resources/NDSmartRestartPlan.pdf

Policy_Details: ALL BUSINESSES can remain operational and must adhere to physical distancing.
• RESTAURANTS / BARS / BREWERIES / DISTILLERIES / CASINOS, GYMS / POOLS / HOT
TUBS, and MOVIE THEATRES remain in the same operational status as PHASE ONE, but with an
increase in capacity from 50% to 75%.
• ORGANIZED YOUTH ACTIVITES remain operational and should avoid GATHERING in groups of
more than 50 people in circumstances that do not readily allow for appropriate physical distancing.
• PLACES OF ASSEMBLY including live music venues and bowling alleys can become
operational with reduced capacity and must adhere to physical distancing. Avoid GATHERING in
groups of more than 50 people in circumstances that do not readily allow for appropriate physical
distancing. Cancel gatherings of more than 50 people unless physical distancing can be
maintained.
 Phase Level: 2, Phase Details Source information: https://covid19.mt.gov/Portals/223/Documents/Reopening%20Montana%20Phase%202.pdf?ver=2020-05-20-142015-167

Policy_Details: Six additional counties were identified as hotspots within MS, adding the following counties to the county-specific executive order with tighter social distancing measures to help limit transmission (tighter restrictions than rest of state under "phase" 3, although phases not used to describe reopening in MS). 
Paragraph I of Executive Order 1509 is amended to add Calhoun, Holmes, Lamar, Montgomery, Winston and Yalobusha Counties. For these counties, the statewide Safe Return instituted in Executive Order 1492 as amended and extended by Executive Orders 1496, 1500, 1505, and 1508 shall remain in full force and effect as issued until 8:00 a.m. on Monday, August 3, 2020, subject to the additional limitations and restricts contained in Executive Order 1509.    Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1512.pdf

Policy_Details: """During Phase I, we can gradually start to reopen economic and social activity. This will be a deliberate process, and is flexible to adapt to the situation. Some communities may be able to reopen at a faster rate, while others may need to continue restrictions to keep the virus from spreading. During Phase I, we should limit our activity and interactions and continue to maintain social distancing and practice good hygiene to protect our neighbors and ourselves.

Citizens who feel sick should stay home!
Continue to practice good hygiene, including:
Washing hands with soap and water, or using hand sanitizer, especially after touching frequently used items or surfaces;
Avoiding touching your face;
Sneezing or coughing into a tissue, or the inside of your elbow; and
Disinfecting frequently used items and surfaces as much as possible.
Avoid socializing in groups that do not readily allow for appropriate physical distancing (receptions, trade shows, etc.). When in public (parks, outdoor recreation spaces, shopping malls, etc.), individuals should maximize physical distance from others.
Minimize travel to the extent possible."""   Source information: https://governor.mo.gov/sites/gov/files/media/pdf/2020/04/Economic-Reopening-Phase-1.pdf

Policy_Details: all restaurants and bars must close at 11:00 pm; tables spaced at least 6 ft apart; indoor tables limited to groups of 6; bar stools must be removed from the bar area (ordering, seating, congregating at bar area is prohibited); each party must have a reservation (even if made on-site) to ensure that the restaurant/bar has contact information for contact tracing    Source information: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2020-51.aspx

Policy_Details: Executive order signed by governor, statewide Cooper signed an executive order modifying the stay-at-home order and transitioning the state into Phase 1 of easing restrictions, effective 5:00 p.m. on May 8. The order will last until at least May 22. The modified order removes the distinction between essential and nonessential businesses. Retail businesses may operate at 50% capacity and must implement health and safety measures for workers and customers. Cloth face coverings are recommended for workers, and teleworking is encouraged whenever possible. In Phase 1, restaurants remain limited to drive-through, takeout and delivery service. Bars, personal care businesses, entertainment venues and gyms will stay closed. Child care facilities can be open during Phase 1, subject to strict cleaning protocols, to serve families of parents who are working or looking for work. Summer day camps can operate in compliance with state guidelines. Phase Level: 1, Phase Details Source information: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO121-Stay-at-Home-Order-3.pdf

Policy_Details: This Executive Order amends, restates, and replaces
Executive Order Nos. 141, 153, 162, and 163 in full, except where this Executive Order
incorporates provisions of Executive Order No. 163 as if they were stated herein. Those
incorporated provisions of Executive Order No. 163 are extended for the duration of this
Executive Order, including any extensions or amendments of this Executive Order. 

Mass Gatherings are prohibited. "Mass Gathering" means an event or
convening that brings together more than twenty-five (25) people indoors or more than
fifty (50) people outdoors at the same time in a single confined indoor or outdoor space.    Source information: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO169-Phase-3.pdf

Policy_Details: " Salons
As of May 4th, beauty/nail salons, barber shops, massage therapy services, and tattoo parlors/studios in the above LHDs will be permitted to open.  These establishments will be added to the list of gatherings subject to the 10-person rule.
The new DHM will require both workers and patrons of these establishments to wear masks.
For districts other than those listed above, these establishments will remain closed past May 3rd.
•       Restaurants
As of May 4th, restaurants will be allowed to serve dine-in customers if all of the following conditions are met:
   The restaurant limits seating to 50% of the rated occupancy maximum at all times.
   The restaurant seats parties at least six feet apart.
   All dining parties are restricted to no more than six persons (groups larger than six will need to sit at separate tables).
   Self-serve buffets and salad bars are prohibited.  Restaurant staff must serve food directly to customers or implement buffet orders from the customer table.  No customer self-service will be allowed.
   Bar seating is not permitted.
   Patrons may only consume alcohol on the premises if also consuming a meal.
Bars that do not serve food will remain limited to carry-out sales and delivery only.
For districts other than those listed above, restaurants will remain limited to delivery, drive-thru, or carryout past May 3rd.

•       Childcare Facilities
 As of May 4th, childcare facilities will be permitted to have up to 15 kids per room/space.
    All other state provisions, statutes, and regulations (including child-to-staff ratios) still apply.
    For districts other than those listed above, childcares will remain restricted to 10 children per room/space.

•       Other Establishments
Bars, gentlemen’s clubs, bottle clubs, indoor movie theaters, indoor theaters/playhouses will remain closed statewide until May 31st, though the State may revise the DHM prior to that date."   Source information: https://governor.nebraska.gov/press/gov-ricketts-announces-upcoming-changes-directed-health-measures-deploys-additional-resources

comments: Policy_Details: On May 22, the state entered its second phase of reopening. Bars, bowling alleys, bingo halls and rodeo events were allowed to open with additional guidelines, including occupancy limits. On May 31, certain professional sports leagues will be allowed to reopen without fans. On June 1, in-person summer school classes will be able to resume with additional guidelines. Policy_Details: Governor Henry McMaster signed executive order 2020-50 in which counties and municipalities are encouraged to implement appropriate and narrowly tailored emergency ordinances, orders, or other measures requiring individuals to wear face coverings in public settings where social distancing is not possible. Restaurants shall require that all employees, customers, patrons, suppliers, vendors, and other visitors wear Face Coverings, except while actively engaged in eating or drinking and subject to any applicable exceptions. Order shall remain in effect for the duration of the State of Emergency.   Source information: https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/2020-08-02%20eFILED%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202020-50%20-%20Initiating%20Additional%20Emergency%20Measures%20%26%20Consolidating%20Previous%20Orders.pdf

Policy_Details: Restaurants, bars, nightclubs, similar establishments may open with restrictions

Not serve customers who are not seated
Clean/disinfect each table between each seating  Phase Level: 2, Phase Details Source information: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Gatherings-NINTH-AMENDED-6.10.20.pdf
