Policy_Details: OFFICES
• Continue capacity limit of no more than 50% occupancy
• In-person meetings of up to 50 people with social distancing permitted
• Continue health screenings, though employers may screen office
employees via in-person conversation or questionnaire once at their
workstation, or using virtual method 

RETAIL AND SERVICE COUNTER
• Continue capacity limit of no more than 50% occupancy
• Mall food courts may reopen in line with Indoor Dining and
Drinking guidelines

PERSONAL CARE
• Continue capacity limit of no more than 50% occupancy
• If services require customer to remove his or her mask, employee
must wear both a face mask and eye protection (e.g., face shield,
protective glasses)
• No time restrictions on massage or other services

FILM PRODUCTION
• Capacity limit of no more than 50% of sound stage/location occupancy
• Crowd scenes should be limited to 50 people or fewer
• All individuals should maintain 6 ft. of social distancing unless job duty
cannot be performed without proximity (e.g. actors performing, hair, makeup, costumes)
• One-time nasal swab for RT-PCR testing of all cast and crew should be
obtained within 48 to 72 hours prior to the start of work on set or location
• Craft services and catering should follow Restaurant and Bar guidelines
• Live audiences permitted in line with Theatre/Performing Arts guidelines 

MEETINGS AND SOCIAL EVENTS
• Limit to the lesser of 50 people or 50% of room capacity
• Multiple groups may meet in the same facility if they are socially distanced
and in separate rooms
• Groups should be static for duration of meeting or event. If event includes
multiple sessions, participants should remain in one room, and speakers/
presenters should rotate between rooms or be digitally displayed (e.g.
projected, livestreamed) in multiple rooms
• Dance floors should remain closed
• Food service should follow Restaurant and Bar guidelines   Source information: https://dceocovid19resources.com/assets/Restore-Illinois/businessguidelines4/phase4overview.pdf

Policy_Details: Starting Monday, May 4, 2020, retail businesses will be allowed to sell goods through delivery service, window service, walk-up service, drive-through service, drive-up service or curbside delivery provided they establish and implement sanitation and physical distancing measures. Policy_Details: 
-Employees must wear proper face coverings
-Perform frequent hand hygiene (with soap and water or alcohol-based hand sanitizer).1. Restaurants and other licensed food establishments, including taverns, nightclubs, and mixed-use facilities that serve food, may continue to operate with seated outdoor eating and drinking.
- Restaurants and other licensed food establishments may open for indoor dining with the following minimum safeguards:
-All indoor dining/drinking customers must be seated, place orders, and be served at tables;
-. No more than six (6) individuals may be seated indoors at a table or a joined table, and indoor and outdoor fixed tables that accommodate larger groups than are permitted may demarcate six (6) feet between groups and allow seating at those large tables;
- Bar seating is prohibited if any bartender is working at that bar;
- All tables must be placed so that patrons are at least six (6) feet apart;
- All restaurants and licensed food establishments must implement sanitization and disinfection protocols
- Darts, pool, billiards, ping-pong, pinball, playgrounds, and other activities that are not carried out seated at tables are prohibited
- No queuing indoors shall be allowed, and outdoors, patrons must be separated by at least six (6) feet.
- Restaurants and other licensed food establishments may serve customers up to fifty percent (50%) of their maximum capacity
- Restaurants and other licensed food establishments are encouraged to use a reservation system, preferably online or by telephone, to avoid crowding and queuing nearby.-
- Restaurants and other licensed food establishments are encouraged to keep customer logs to facilitate contact tracing if necessary.   Source information: https://coronavirus.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/coronavirus/page_content/attachments/COVID-19_DC_Health_Guidance_for_Restaurants_08202020.pdf

Policy_Details: -Employees and patrons must wear a cloth face covering at all times
-Gloves must be worn only as indicated per routine job responsibilities.
•Perform frequent hand hygiene (with soap and water or alcohol-based hand sanitizer).
-Avoid Close Contact and Reduce Touch points for Patrons and Employees(indoor barriers, encourage online shopping, make one way paths etc.)
-Employers must perform screening (e.g., symptom questionnaires) of employees daily,
prior to entering the business, over the phone or in person
-sick employees must not enter workplace ; if sick at work must immediately be separated and sent home.
-Limits the number of persons in the establishment at 50% of occupancy as specified on the Certificate of Occupancy and establishes processes. Policy_Details: Governor Carney announced Phase 2 of Delaware's reopening will begin June 15, 2020
INDIVIDUAL GUIDELINES
-Cloth coverings must be worn
-Non-household members must maximize social distancing
-All individuals in public (parks, outdoor recreation areas, shopping, etc) must social distance
-Indoor gathering limit: 50 people but social distance from non-household members
-Places operating at 30% occupancy under Phase 1 can move to 60% occupancy 
-Exercise facilities and personal care services (hair, tanning, tattoo, massage, nail, brow, spas) to remain at 30% occupancy
-Fully unenclosed outdoor gatherings of up to 250 people are permitted
-Leisure travel should be avoided but may resume under general guidance
-All vulnerable individuals should continue to shelter in place
BUSINESS GUIDELINES
-Common areas where people can congregate must remain closed
-Employees/customers have responsibility to self-quarantine if they think they may be sick
-Teleworking is encouraged
-All surfaces touched by customers must be disinfected by EPA-approved disinfectant every 15 minutes to 2 hours 
-Employees required to go to work should perform daily health work 
-All employees must wash hands throughout the day and use hand sanitizer and social distance from other employees
-Businesses must make hand sanitizer available to employees and patrons (hand sanitizer must be 60% ethanol and 70% isopropanol 
-Downtime should be given between shifts and after closing for cleaning 
-Employees must post signs about how to stop spread of COVID-19, hand hygiene, and wear a face covering  Phase Level: 2, Phase Details Source information: https://governor.delaware.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/24/2020/06/Delaware-Economic-Reopening-PHASE-2.pdf

Policy_Details: Physical distancing with table spacing and occupancy limit. Employ disinfection measures like cleaning high contact surfaces, no pre set tableware, and cleaning delivery vehicles. Monitor employ health. Maximize options that allow takeout and delivery. Establish hours for high risk patrons. Increase ventilation in restaurant setting.   Source information: https://rebound.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/stage4-protocols-restaurants.pdf

Policy_Details: Governor Northam issued amended Executive Order 65 easing certain temporary restrictions of businesses
Restaurants, dining establishments, food courts, breweries, microbreweries, distilleries, wineries, and tasting rooms may operate delivery, take out, indoor/outdoor dining, and beverage services in compliance with guidelines
Occupancy may not exceed 50% 
All parties must be limited to 50 patrons or less
Tables at which dining parties are seated must be positioned 6 ft apart
No self service of food (except beverages) and including condiments 
Bar seats must be closed to patrons except for through traffic 
Employees must wear face coverings at all times
Cleaning and disinfection of frequently contacted surfaces must be conducted every 60 minutes
If businesses cannot adhere to these guidelines, they must close  Phase Level: 2, Phase Details Source information: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-65-and-Order-Of-Public-Health-Emergency-Six---AMENDED---Phase-Two-Easing-of-Certain-Temporary-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf

Policy_Details: Executive Order by Governor Tate Reeves signed on 7/10, but only applying to Claiborne, Desoto, Grenada, Harrison, Hinds, Jackson, Jefferson, Madison, Quitman, Rnakin, Sunflower, Washington, and Wayne Counties. Amends Safe Return EO 1492/1496/1500/1505 for these counties. 
Gatherings limited to 10 indoors (with social distancing of 6 feet, or with face coverings required when 6 feet is not possible) and 20 outdoors (with social distancing 6 feet, or with face coverings required when 6 ft is not possible).  
Face Coverings required both indoors and outdoors when 6 ft distance not possible when attending public events such as outdoor sports complexes and arenas   Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1507.pdf

Policy_Details: Executive Order by Governor Tate Reeves signed on 7/10, but only applying to Claiborne, Desoto, Grenada, Harrison, Hinds, Jackson, Jefferson, Madison, Quitman, Rnakin, Sunflower, Washington, and Wayne Counties. Amends Safe Return EO 1492/1496/1500/1505 for these counties. 
All businesses should be following relevant guidelines in these counties such as employee screening/reporting daily, social distancing, cleaning, and face coverings when 6 ft not possible.
Retail Businesses should also in addition provide employees with face coverings (when they have contact with public, and these to be cleaned/replaced daily), customers must wear face coverings, hand sanitizer must be provided, 6 ft separation must be kept whenever possible, and sanitation of carts/baskets and high touch areas   Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1507.pdf

Policy_Details: State Health Officer Scott Harris signed 7/15 new Safer at Home Order with face covering requirement as ordered by Governor Kay Ivey's Proclamation from 7/15 effective 7/16 at 5:00pm: all required to wear face coverings when within six feet of a person from another household in any of the following places: an indoor space open to the general public, a vehicle operated by a transportation service, or an outdoor public space where ten or more people are gathered, with exceptions for those age 6 or under, those with relevant medical condition that prevents mask being worn, when eating/drinking, when receiving a service (i.e. personal care) that requires face to be uncovered, for security and safety purposes, when actively exercising or swimming, when essential for effective communication (mouth needs to be visible, or when broadcasting), when voting or attending religious services (strongly encouraged but not required because constitutionally protected activities), when conducting essential job functions for which face covering prevents necessary public safety function (first responders) or is unsafe by industry standards.    Source information: https://governor.alabama.gov/assets/2020/07/Safer-at-Home-Order-Mask-Amendment-7.15.2020-FINAL.pdf

Policy_Details: Currently open: Grocery stores, pharmacies, banks and credit unions, and gas stations are all open.
Restaurants are open for take-out service only.
Stand alone retail operations are open provided they meet required safety and physical distancing guidelines. Indoor and outdoor malls are closed.
Local outdoor recreation activities are open, including many state parks.
Non-emergency medical care, dentist offices and veterinary care are open and operating, provided they meet required safety guidelines.
Local cultural, civic and faith gatherings are allowed for up to 25 people provided physical distancing can be in place.
Local social gatherings over 10 people are prohibited and those under 10 people must use physical distancing.
Personal care services such as salons and barbers, as well as gyms, are closed.
Child care is open under certain restrictions, with priority placements for children of health care workers, first responders, and frontline workers.
Public transit is open under certain restrictions, and must be sanitized often and enforce 3 feet of space between passengers.
Overnight camps are not permitted. Day camps are open with restrictions, including maximum stable groups of 10 or fewer children.
For summer school, limited in-person, small group instruction and/or summer programming is allowed, with certain restrictions.
 Phase Level: 1, Phase Details Source information: https://govstatus.egov.com/reopening-oregon#phase1

Policy_Details: Governor Northam issued amended Executive Order 65 easing certain temporary restrictions on businesses Fitness centers, gyms, recreation centers, sports facilities, and exercise facilities may reopen for indoor and outdoor activities Patrons, members, guests must remain at least 10 ft apart Instructors and participants of group exercise must remain at least 10 ft apart Total # of attendees in group exercise and fitness classes can't exceed the lesser of 30% of minimum occupancy load Hot tubs, spas, splash pads, spray pools, interactive pool must be closed Outdoor/indoor swimming pools may open for lap swimming, diving, exercise, instruction and must be limited to no more than 3 people per lane with 10 ft between each swimmer Employees must wear face coverings at all times Ensure cleaning and disinfection Facilities shall prohibit any equipment that can't be thoroughly cleaned Supply hand sanitizer or hand washing stations If a business can't adhere, it must close Phase Level: 2, Phase Details Source information: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-65-and-Order-Of-Public-Health-Emergency-Six---AMENDED---Phase-Two-Easing-of-Certain-Temporary-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf

Policy_Details: Pools: Limit the number of people in the facility at a time to ensure physical distancing. Limit use of indoor facilities. Direct the flow of patrons and employees through the facility to reduce person to person contact. Strictly monitor the use of the kiddie pool or other congregate areas. Thoroughly disinfect all surfaces and all equipment after each user. Employee face masks. Do not allow symptomatic persons entry. Use hand sanitizer or wash hands at the entrance to the facility upon arrival and departure. Provide soap, water, and alcohol-based hand rubs in multiple locations and routinely refill.

Gyms: Limit the number of people in the facility at a time to ensure physical distancing. Move activities outside if possible, and make sure there is optimal ventilation for inside activities. Direct the flow of patrons and staff through the facility to reduce person-to-person contact. Space exercise equipment at least six feet apart. Monitor employee health. Make hand sanitizer available at the entrance, in locker rooms, and throughout the facility. Shared equipment disinfected after each use.    Source information: https://rebound.idaho.gov/business-specific-protocols-for-opening/

Policy_Details: Governor Abbot issued Executive Order No. GA-26: Phase 3- businesses to open to no more than 50% capacity, but no occupancy limits for houses of worship, child care, youth camps, govt operations, outdoor areas/events (pools, water parks, zoos, rodeos, etc.), and personal care establishments given 6 ft between work stations; also public schools to resume (private/higher ed encouraged to), no requirement for wearing/penalty for not wearing face coverings. Governor Greg Abbot Executive Order GA-26: 50% capacity open allowed for all TX establishments, and some activities are exempt from this occupancy requirement: there is no occupancy limit for houses or worship, child care, some types of government work, summer camps/youth camps, and sports programs for adults and children, personal care establishments e.g. cosmetology and massage (as long as 6 ft between workstations) and outdoor areas (w/ exception of professional, collegiate, or similar sporting events, swimming pools, water parks, museums and libraries, zoos, aquariums, natural caverns, etc. and rodeos and equestrian events: all of these must not be operating at more than 50% normal operating limits) Phase Level: 3, Phase Details Source information: https://gov.texas.gov/uploads/files/press/EO-GA-26_expanded_opening_COVID-19.pdf, https://www.dshs.state.tx.us/coronavirus/opentexas.aspx

Policy_Details: Governor Carney announced Phase 2 of Delaware's reopening will begin June 15, 2020
INDIVIDUAL GUIDELINES
-Cloth coverings must be worn
-Non-household members must maximize social distancing
-All individuals in public (parks, outdoor recreation areas, shopping, etc) must social distance
-Indoor gathering limit: 50 people but social distance from non-household members
-Places operating at 30% occupancy under Phase 1 can move to 60% occupancy 
-Exercise facilities and personal care services (hair, tanning, tattoo, massage, nail, brow, spas) to remain at 30% occupancy
-Fully unenclosed outdoor gatherings of up to 250 people are permitted
-Leisure travel should be avoided but may resume under general guidance
-All vulnerable individuals should continue to shelter in place
BUSINESS GUIDELINES
-Common areas where people can congregate must remain closed
-Employees/customers have responsibility to self-quarantine if they think they may be sick
-Teleworking is encouraged
-All surfaces touched by customers must be disinfected by EPA-approved disinfectant every 15 minutes to 2 hours 
-Employees required to go to work should perform daily health work 
-All employees must wash hands throughout the day and use hand sanitizer and social distance from other employees
-Businesses must make hand sanitizer available to employees and patrons (hand sanitizer must be 60% ethanol and 70% isopropanol 
-Downtime should be given between shifts and after closing for cleaning 
-Employees must post signs about how to stop spread of COVID-19, hand hygiene, and wear a face covering  Phase Level: 2, Phase Details Source information: https://governor.delaware.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/24/2020/06/Delaware-Economic-Reopening-PHASE-2.pdf

Policy_Details: Region 8 indoor cinemas, convention centers, performance spaces, meeting halls, sports arenas, and theaters open at 25% capacity or 250 people (whichever is smaller); outdoor concert spaces, race tracks, sports arenas, and stadiums open at 25% capacity or 500 people (whichever is smaller)    Source information: https://www.michigan.gov/whitmer/0,9309,7-387-90499_90705-535195--,00.html

Policy_Details: " Salons
As of May 4th, beauty/nail salons, barber shops, massage therapy services, and tattoo parlors/studios in the above LHDs will be permitted to open.  These establishments will be added to the list of gatherings subject to the 10-person rule.
The new DHM will require both workers and patrons of these establishments to wear masks.
For districts other than those listed above, these establishments will remain closed past May 3rd.
•       Restaurants
As of May 4th, restaurants will be allowed to serve dine-in customers if all of the following conditions are met:
   The restaurant limits seating to 50% of the rated occupancy maximum at all times.
   The restaurant seats parties at least six feet apart.
   All dining parties are restricted to no more than six persons (groups larger than six will need to sit at separate tables).
   Self-serve buffets and salad bars are prohibited.  Restaurant staff must serve food directly to customers or implement buffet orders from the customer table.  No customer self-service will be allowed.
   Bar seating is not permitted.
   Patrons may only consume alcohol on the premises if also consuming a meal.
Bars that do not serve food will remain limited to carry-out sales and delivery only.
For districts other than those listed above, restaurants will remain limited to delivery, drive-thru, or carryout past May 3rd.

•       Childcare Facilities
 As of May 4th, childcare facilities will be permitted to have up to 15 kids per room/space.
    All other state provisions, statutes, and regulations (including child-to-staff ratios) still apply.
    For districts other than those listed above, childcares will remain restricted to 10 children per room/space.

•       Other Establishments
Bars, gentlemen’s clubs, bottle clubs, indoor movie theaters, indoor theaters/playhouses will remain closed statewide until May 31st, though the State may revise the DHM prior to that date."   Source information: https://governor.nebraska.gov/press/gov-ricketts-announces-upcoming-changes-directed-health-measures-deploys-additional-resources

Policy_Details: Governor Polis released public health order revising Safer at Home, and in the Vast, Great Outdoors
-Private campgrounds may open and campground operators must regularly clean & disinfect areas
-Group facilities, pavilions, cabins, yurts remain closed
-Campsites must be 6 ft apart, only available by reservation 
-Limit visitors in campground offices to maintain such distancing 
PERSONAL RECREATION 
-Personal recreation (playgrounds, outdoors sports facilities) at a maximum of 25 people 
-Outdoor swimming pools open at 50% occupancy, no more than 50 people 
-Organized recreational youth/adult league sports can start with no more than 25 players outdoors or 10 players indoors, parents can attend youth sports but remain 6 ft apart from non-household members, spectators discouraged at adult sports & sports league must retain records of players in case of later outbreak
-Gyms, recreation centers, indoor pools open at 25% occupancy, not to exceed 50 people, restrooms and showers open but lockers are closed
-Competitive events (races, endurance events) permitted with 6 ft distancing and limit on group size
OUTDOOR RECREATION 
-Outdoor recreation is permitted with non-guided recreation groups no larger than 10 people
-Guide services for fishing, hunting, biking, horseback riding, canoeing, kayaking, stand up paddle boarding, ATV tours, climbing permitted with groups no more than 10 people
-River outfitters, rafting, Jeep tours in groups up to 2 households in a boat or groups of no more than 10 in Jeep
-Developed hot springs may operate following outdoor pool requirements
-Outdoor recreation activities at ski resorts if local public health agency has reviewed & approved resort's plans 
-Outdoor recreation activities not at ski resorts if local public health agency has reviewed & approved plans 
-Scenic trains if every local public health agency in each jurisdiction train operates reviews and approves train's plans 
-Trail and conservation crew no larger than 10    Source information: https://covid19.colorado.gov/covid-19-in-colorado/public-health-executive-orders-resource

Policy_Details: Large indoor venues like theaters, museums, and funeral homes and large outdoor venues like arenas and concert halls can have up to 100 people inside at a time, and can increase to 66% capacity only if a plan is approved by the Secretary of Health.

Casinos, restaurants, and bars allowed to increase capacity to 66 percent.

All staff who come into regular contact with customers must continue to wear a mask.

Anyone who comes into these facilities must wear a face covering as well, and all groups must stay six feet apart from each other.   Source information: https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/programs-services/topics/covid-19-health-guidances, https://www.nwahomepage.com/lifestyle/health/coronavirus/arkansas-moves-into-phase-two-of-reopening/

Policy_Details: Executive Order 2020-586: Signed 7/19 by Governor Andy Beshear. Effective 7/10 at 5 pm for 30 days. Face coverings must be worn when in line for or inside grocery store/pharmacy, retail establishment, personal care establishment, daycare/childcare facility, restaurant/food establishment, healthcare setting, any other indoor public place where social distancing is not possible, while waiting for or using public transportation or ride sharing, and while in an outdoor public setting where social distancing of 6 feet is not possible between members of different households.  Exceptions for anyone 5 and under, disability making mask wearing not possible safely, when communicating with someone who is hearing impaired or conducting a broadcast, for safety reasons if performing a task that would be deemed unsafe by the state to be wearing a face covering for, when receiving a service that requires the face to be uncovered, for safety/security reasons, when actively exercising, swimming, eating or drinking.    Source information: https://govsite-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/A59NLcxVTFG7ioyvncMY_20200709_Executive-Order_State-of-Emergency.pdf

Policy_Details: Stay at home order ended by governor on april 30th, statewide. Executive order to enter phase one.  Texas' stay-at-home order ended April 30. Gov. Greg Abbott allowed retail stores, restaurants, movie theaters, malls, and museums to operate at 25% capacity starting May 1, saying businesses should operate with social distancing and sanitation measures in mind. Under Abbott's "Open Texas" plan, personal care businesses such as barbershops, hair salons, and tanning salons were allowed to resume operations starting on May 8. Gyms and exercise facilities, manufacturers, and offices are permitted to reopen on May 18, and must keep social distancing and sanitation requirements in mind. There have been no further announcements of how Texas will further ease restrictions. Public swimming pools, bars, interactive amusement venues, such as bowling alleys, and tattoo parlors remain closed. Phase Level: 1, Phase Details Source information: https://gov.texas.gov/uploads/files/press/EO-GA-18_expanded_reopening_of_services_COVID-19.pdf, https://gov.texas.gov/news/post/governor-abbott-announces-phase-one-to-open-texas-establishes-statewide-minimum-standard-health-protocols

Policy_Details: This is NOT an SIP/SAH.  It is a Public Health Disaster Emergency Proclamation

"Today, [5/13/20] Governor Reynolds signed a new proclamation continuing the Public Health Disaster Emergency. The proclamation permits salons, barbershops, and massage and tattoo establishments to reopen throughout Iowa in a limited fashion with appropriate public health measures in place. It also permits restaurants (but not bars), fitness centers, libraries, and race tracks to reopen in the 22 counties where they have remained closed. These changes are effective at 5:00 a.m. on Friday, May 15.

The proclamation continues the other ongoing closures and public health measures, including the prohibition on social, community, recreational, leisure, and sporting gatherings and events of more than 10 people, until 11:59 p.m. on May 27, 2020."    Source information: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.05.13.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery

Policy_Details: New Mexico's stay at home restrictions were modified on April 30, with an extension of the state's stay-at-home order in place until May 15.
New Mexicans must remain home except for outings essential for health, safety and welfare, especially elderly and vulnerable individuals. If you must leave home, gatherings of more than five people remain prohibited and 6 feet of physical distance from others must be maintained.
Large retailers like big-box stores and grocery stores will continue operating at 20 percent capacity as determined by fire code.  
Other high-intensity contact services that must remain closed include indoor malls, massage and tattoo parlors, theaters, casinos.
WHAT WILL CHANGE BEGINNING MAY 16:
All retailers may operate according to COVID-Safe Practices (“CSPs”) at 25 percent fire code occupancy (a “retailer” is any business that sells goods directly to the ultimate consumer or end-users and does not include wholesalers or suppliers, not does it include entertainment venues such as movie theaters, concert halls, or amusement parks);
Non-essential businesses (other than retailers; such as office spaces, call centers) generally may operate according to CSPs at up to 25 percent of pre-crisis staffing levels. All employees should continue to work from home wherever possible;
   Source information: https://cv.nmhealth.org/2020/05/13/stay-at-home-order-extended/

Policy_Details: New Mexico's stay at home restrictions were modified on April 30, with an extension of the state's stay-at-home order in place until May 15.
New Mexicans must remain home except for outings essential for health, safety and welfare, especially elderly and vulnerable individuals. If you must leave home, gatherings of more than five people remain prohibited and 6 feet of physical distance from others must be maintained.
Locations and services where high-intensity contact is unavoidable – such as dine-in service at restaurants and bars – will remain temporarily closed. Limited in-person operations for those types of businesses could be included in the next modification of the public health order, as soon as early June, depending on New Mexico’s rate of COVID-19 transmission, testing capacity and other gating criteria.
Other high-intensity contact services that must remain closed include theaters, casinos.   Source information: https://cv.nmhealth.org/2020/05/13/stay-at-home-order-extended/

Policy_Details: Governor Carney announced Phase 2 of Delaware's reopening will begin June 15, 2020 INDIVIDUAL GUIDELINES -Cloth coverings must be worn -Non-household members must maximize social distancing -All individuals in public (parks, outdoor recreation areas, shopping, etc) must social distance -Indoor gathering limit: 50 people but social distance from non-household members -Places operating at 30% occupancy under Phase 1 can move to 60% occupancy -Exercise facilities and personal care services (hair, tanning, tattoo, massage, nail, brow, spas) to remain at 30% occupancy -Fully unenclosed outdoor gatherings of up to 250 people are permitted -Leisure travel should be avoided but may resume under general guidance -All vulnerable individuals should continue to shelter in place BUSINESS GUIDELINES -Common areas where people can congregate must remain closed -Employees/customers have responsibility to self-quarantine if they think they may be sick -Teleworking is encouraged -All surfaces touched by customers must be disinfected by EPA-approved disinfectant every 15 minutes to 2 hours -Employees required to go to work should perform daily health work -All employees must wash hands throughout the day and use hand sanitizer and social distance from other employees -Businesses must make hand sanitizer available to employees and patrons (hand sanitizer must be 60% ethanol and 70% isopropanol -Downtime should be given between shifts and after closing for cleaning -Employees must post signs about how to stop spread of COVID-19, hand hygiene, and wear a face covering Phase Level: 2, Phase Details Source information: https://governor.delaware.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/24/2020/06/Delaware-Economic-Reopening-PHASE-2.pdf

Policy_Details: THEATERS AND PERFORMING ARTS:
• Seated theaters, cinemas, and performing arts centers for ticketed
events with seating available for all customers permitted; general
admission shows and/or events with standing room only are not
permitted at this time
• Indoor capacity limit of 50 people or less or 50% of space capacity
(applies to each screening room); outdoor capacity limited to 20% of
overall space capacity
• Patrons should wear face coverings over their nose and mouth, except
while seated within a venue (exceptions can be made for people with
medical conditions or disabilities that prevent them from safely wearing a
face covering)
• Concessions permitted with restrictions

OUTDOOR SEATED SPECTATOR EVENTS
• Outdoor spectator events only; indoor spectator events not permitted at
this time
• Tickets events with seating available for all customers permitted; general
admission shows and/or events with standing room only are not permitted
at this time
• Maximum of 20% of seating capacity for spectators
• Concessions permitted with restrictions

MUSEUMS:
• Capacity limit of no more than 25% occupancy
• Guided tours should be limited to 50 or fewer people per group
• Hands-on exhibits and touch screens should be closed or modified to
eliminate the hands-on component
• Audio tours are permitted, though equipment should be disinfected before
and after individual use
• Museums should have plan to limit congregation via advance ticket sales
and timed ticketing
• Concessions permitted with restrictions

ZOOS:
• Capacity limit of no more than 25% occupancy
• Guided tours should be limited to 50 or fewer people per group
• Hands-on exhibits and touch screens should be closed or modified
to eliminate the hands-on component
• Indoor exhibits should be closed
• Audio tours are permitted, though
equipment should be disinfected
before and after individual use
• Zoos should have plan to limit
congregation via advance ticket
sales and timed ticketing
• Concessions permitted with
restrictions   Source information: https://dceocovid19resources.com/assets/Restore-Illinois/businessguidelines4/phase4overview.pdf

Policy_Details: Greg Abbott issued Executive Order No. GA-29 relating to the use of face coverings during the COVID- 19 disaster on July 2. Every person in Texas shall wear a face covering over the nose and mouth when inside a commercial entity or other building or space open to the public, or when in an outdoor public space, wherever it is not feasible to maintain six feet of social distancing from another person not in the same household; provided, however, that this face-covering requirement does not apply to children under 10, medical exemptions/disabilities, when eating, swimming, or exercising (with distance), when driving only with those of same household, for security reasons, and when involved or observing in religious services or assisting or participating in process of voting (but strongly encouraged). Counties with cases under 20 who have opted out of requirement also exempt.   Source information: https://open.texas.gov/uploads/files/organization/opentexas/EO-GA-29-use-of-face-coverings-during-COVID-19-IMAGE-07-02-2020.pdf

Policy_Details: -When leaving their residence or visiting the District, all individuals must continue to maintain a distance of at least six feet from persons not in their household, except if such distance is impossible to maintain (ex: obtaining medical services or salon services)

-During Phase Two, if the District no longer meets the criteria for Phase Two, the Executive may order more stringent measures to contain the spread of COVID-19 and address the changing circumstances of the public health emergency.   Source information: https://coronavirus.dc.gov/phasetwo

Policy_Details: "All businesses and employers are encouraged to adopt and/or take the following
actions:
Businesses should encourage customers to wear FACE COVERINGS.
Continue to encourage TELEWORK, whenever possible and feasible with business operations.
If possible, have employees RETURN TO WORK IN PHASES.
CLOSE COMMON AREAS where personnel are likely to congregate and interact, or enforce strict social
distancing protocols.
Follow guidance from the NEVADA LABOR COMMISSIONER regarding sick leave policies.
Strongly consider SPECIAL ACCOMMODATIONS for employees who are members of a vulnerable
population.
Consider encouraging employees to do a SELF-ASSESSMENT each day in order to check if they have
any COVID-19 type symptoms (fever, cough or shortness of breath).
Remind employees to STAY HOME WHEN SICK, use cough and sneeze etiquette, and practice hand
hygiene.
Frequently perform enhanced ENVIRONMENTAL CLEANING of commonly touched surfaces.
Social Distancing & Sanitation Practices in Businesses - All businesses should consider proactive
measures to help protect staff and customers, including but not limited to:
• Implementing separate operating hours for the elderly and vulnerable customers.
• Designating with signage, tape or by other means, six feet of spacing for employees, customers,
clients or members to maintain appropriate distance.
• Having hand sanitizer, and sanitizing products, readily available for employees and customers."   Source information: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Declaration-of-Emergency-Directive-018.Phase-1-Reopening.5-7-20-1.pdf

Policy_Details: Governor Polis issued a revised version of Safer at Home, and in the Vast, Great Outdoors

-Outdoor worship services can attain approval for maximum numbers of individuals and must maintain 6 ft apart from non-household members
-Face coverings are encouraged to be worn by staff, volunteers, and congregants, unless the person is under 2 years old, has trouble breathing, or those who can't remove a mask without assistance
-Houses of worship must follow guidelines for cleaning and disinfecting their buildings before, during, and after worship

Policy_Details: Executive Order by Governor Tate Reeves signed on 7/10, but only applying to Claiborne, Desoto, Grenada, Harrison, Hinds, Jackson, Jefferson, Madison, Quitman, Rnakin, Sunflower, Washington, and Wayne Counties. Amends Safe Return EO 1492/1496/1500/1505 for these counties. 
All businesses should be following relevant guidelines in these counties such as employee screening/reporting daily, social distancing, cleaning, and face coverings when 6 ft not possible.
Retail Businesses should also in addition provide employees with face coverings (when they have contact with public, and these to be cleaned/replaced daily), customers must wear face coverings, hand sanitizer must be provided, 6 ft separation must be kept whenever possible, and sanitation of carts/baskets and high touch areas   Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1507.pdf

Policy_Details: Currently open: Grocery stores, pharmacies, banks and credit unions, and gas stations are all open. Restaurants are open for take-out service only. Stand alone retail operations are open provided they meet required safety and physical distancing guidelines. Indoor and outdoor malls are closed. Local outdoor recreation activities are open, including many state parks. Non-emergency medical care, dentist offices and veterinary care are open and operating, provided they meet required safety guidelines. Local cultural, civic and faith gatherings are allowed for up to 25 people provided physical distancing can be in place. Local social gatherings over 10 people are prohibited and those under 10 people must use physical distancing. Personal care services such as salons and barbers, as well as gyms, are closed. Child care is open under certain restrictions, with priority placements for children of health care workers, first responders, and frontline workers. Public transit is open under certain restrictions, and must be sanitized often and enforce 3 feet of space between passengers. Overnight camps are not permitted. Day camps are open with restrictions, including maximum stable groups of 10 or fewer children. For summer school, limited in-person, small group instruction and/or summer programming is allowed, with certain restrictions. Phase Level: 1, Phase Details Source information: https://govstatus.egov.com/reopening-oregon#phase1

Policy_Details: Six additional counties were identified as hotspots within MS, adding the following counties to the county-specific executive order with tighter social distancing measures to help limit transmission (tighter restrictions than rest of state under "phase" 3, although phases not used to describe reopening in MS). 
Paragraph I of Executive Order 1509 is amended to add Calhoun, Holmes, Lamar, Montgomery, Winston and Yalobusha Counties. For these counties, the statewide Safe Return instituted in Executive Order 1492 as amended and extended by Executive Orders 1496, 1500, 1505, and 1508 shall remain in full force and effect as issued until 8:00 a.m. on Monday, August 3, 2020, subject to the additional limitations and restricts contained in Executive Order 1509.    Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1512.pdf

Policy_Details: """The previous statewide Stay-at-Home and mass gatherings orders are
lifted and mass gatherings of more than 10 individuals are prohibited.
[...]

Industries or functions that are already in operation pursuant to KEFF
may continue to function while, if possible, avoiding gatherings of more
than 10 individuals where social distancing measures are difficult to
maintain.

Any local government that decides to impose equal or more stringent
restrictions during this phase is permitted to do so, except with regards
to essential functions in KEFF.
Any federal restrictions imposed and still in effect must be followed."" (p.9 of pdf in Source)"   Source information: https://covid.ks.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Reopen-Kansas-Framework-v5-1.pdf

Policy_Details: Staff that comes within 6 ft of customers should wear face coverings
Employees should be screened for symptoms of COVID-19 prior to each shift 
Business should maintain record of staff working hours for COVID-19 contact tracing
Close contact group activities (sports) prohibited, personal training permitted
Locker rooms may open, must be assigned by patron and are disinfected after each use, shower may open
Workout equipment at least 6 ft apart and cleaned after each use
Handwashing stations or hand sanitizer readily available
Group workout classes are permitted, remain 6 ft apart, limited to 50 participants
Occupancy must not exceed 1 person per 120 sq ft 
Swimming pools may open with no more than 1 person per 120 sq ft 
Spas, steam rooms, saunas may open with social distancing 
Business shall not operate without appropriate PPE 
Signage posted reminding customers not to enter if they have symptoms of COVID-19
 Phase Level: 2, Phase Details Source information: https://covid19.wyo.gov/governors-orders

- Operate under heightened hygiene and cleaning standards.

Policy_Details: Gatherings (planned or spontaneous event, public or private, indoor or outdoor) of more than 50 people are prohibited 
Hotels/motels for lodging purposes, livestock auctions, groups of workers being transported for jobs, government business/facilities, relief facilities, residential buildings, grocery stores, truck stops, retail/business establishments, healthcare facilities, alcohol and drug treatment centers, long term care/assisted living facilities, religious or faith based organizations, funeral homes, parades are exempt from this order
Events not specifically identified by name or type within order may allow indoor and outdoor gatherings of more than 50 people but no more than 250 people (rodeos, speedway motor races, outdoor concerts, sporting events, fairs, track/field races, farmer's markets, firework shows, weddings)
Groups of attendees must be limited to 6 
6ft distance between individual groups
# of people in confined area must be limited to allow for adequate distancing between households
Close contact between members of different households is prohibited before, during, after event
Staff, host/organizers of event, event participants must be screened for symptoms of COVID-19 prior to event 
Entire event facility shall be cleaned thoroughly
Staff who come within 6 ft of event attendees must wear face covering
Face coverings must be worn by individual groups if 6 ft is not possible 
Event shall not take place without appropriate PPE for staff
Encourage contactless and non-signature payment
Signage reminding attendees not to enter if they have symptoms of COVID-19
Participants in sporting events shall not congregate in groups larger than 50 people
 Phase Level: 2, Phase Details Source information: https://covid19.wyo.gov/governors-orders

Policy_Details: "All businesses and employers are encouraged to adopt and/or take the following
actions:
Businesses should encourage customers to wear FACE COVERINGS.
Continue to encourage TELEWORK, whenever possible and feasible with business operations.
If possible, have employees RETURN TO WORK IN PHASES.
CLOSE COMMON AREAS where personnel are likely to congregate and interact, or enforce strict social
distancing protocols.
Follow guidance from the NEVADA LABOR COMMISSIONER regarding sick leave policies.
Strongly consider SPECIAL ACCOMMODATIONS for employees who are members of a vulnerable
population.
Consider encouraging employees to do a SELF-ASSESSMENT each day in order to check if they have
any COVID-19 type symptoms (fever, cough or shortness of breath).
Remind employees to STAY HOME WHEN SICK, use cough and sneeze etiquette, and practice hand
hygiene.
Frequently perform enhanced ENVIRONMENTAL CLEANING of commonly touched surfaces.
Social Distancing & Sanitation Practices in Businesses - All businesses should consider proactive
measures to help protect staff and customers, including but not limited to:
• Implementing separate operating hours for the elderly and vulnerable customers.
• Designating with signage, tape or by other means, six feet of spacing for employees, customers,
clients or members to maintain appropriate distance.
• Having hand sanitizer, and sanitizing products, readily available for employees and customers."   Source information: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Declaration-of-Emergency-Directive-018.Phase-1-Reopening.5-7-20-1.pdf

Policy_Details: Restaurants offer seating only services. Maximize cleaning service and physical distancing for patrons and staff. Nightclubs can only operate as a bar.    Source information: https://coronavirus.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/stay-healthy-order-stage3_2020oct27.pdf

Policy_Details: Executive Order by Governor Tate Reeves signed on 7/10, but only applying to Claiborne, Desoto, Grenada, Harrison, Hinds, Jackson, Jefferson, Madison, Quitman, Rnakin, Sunflower, Washington, and Wayne Counties. Amends Safe Return EO 1492/1496/1500/1505 for these counties. 
Gatherings limited to 10 indoors (with social distancing of 6 feet, or with face coverings required when 6 feet is not possible) and 20 outdoors (with social distancing 6 feet, or with face coverings required when 6 ft is not possible).  
All businesses should be following relevant guidelines in these counties such as employee screening/reporting daily, social distancing, cleaning, and face coverings when 6 ft not possible.   Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1507.pdf

Policy_Details: No greater than 50 people at indoor venues. Outdoor venues must operate at 25% capacity and follow guidelines. Guidelines include mask wearing, physical distancing, and frequent sanitation. Polling, educational activity, and religious activity are exempt from the gathering limits. Southwest District Health recommends that high risk individuals avoids high exposure events.   Source information: https://twinfallscounty.org/wp-content/uploads/stay-healthy-order-stage3_2020oct27-1.pdf

Policy_Details: Executive Order by Governor Tate Reeves signed on 7/10, but only applying to Claiborne, Desoto, Grenada, Harrison, Hinds, Jackson, Jefferson, Madison, Quitman, Rnakin, Sunflower, Washington, and Wayne Counties. Amends Safe Return EO 1492/1496/1500/1505 for these counties.

Policy_Details: -Childcare providers must perform a daily health screen for all children and staff entering
the childcare facility. An individual with any of the following symptoms must not enter the
facility,
-If an individual develops any of the symptoms there must be a plan in place for that individual to immediately isolate.
- Must maintain hygiene (provide hand sanitizer, soap, etc)
-Childcare providers should ensure that children and staff at increased risk for experiencing severe illness due to COVID-19 consult with their medical provider before participating in childcare activities. (ex: Cancer, immunocompromised conditions, serious heart conditions, sickle cell disease, and or severe obesity)
-All adults must wear non-medical face coverings or face masks at all times while participating in childcare activities.
-Children 2 years of age or younger must not wear face masks. 
-Children above the age of two years have the option of wearing a face mask based on a
joint decision between the parent and the child’s healthcare provider
-Childcare facilities must notify DC Health if employee or child patient tests Positive for Covid-19. 
- Cleaning and disinfecting must be kept up to date and effectively( surfaces, toys, etc)   Source information: https://coronavirus.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/coronavirus/page_content/attachments/COVID-19_DC_Health_Guidance_for-Childcare_2020-08-05.pdf

Policy_Details: """The previous statewide Stay-at-Home and mass gatherings orders are
lifted and mass gatherings of more than 10 individuals are prohibited.
[...]

Industries or functions that are already in operation pursuant to KEFF
may continue to function while, if possible, avoiding gatherings of more
than 10 individuals where social distancing measures are difficult to
maintain.

Any local government that decides to impose equal or more stringent
restrictions during this phase is permitted to do so, except with regards
to essential functions in KEFF.
Any federal restrictions imposed and still in effect must be followed."" (p.9 of pdf in Source)"   Source information: https://covid.ks.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Reopen-Kansas-Framework-v5-1.pdf

Policy_Details: Governor Carney announced Phase 2 of Delaware's reopening will begin June 15, 2020
INDIVIDUAL GUIDELINES
-Cloth coverings must be worn
-Non-household members must maximize social distancing
-All individuals in public (parks, outdoor recreation areas, shopping, etc) must social distance
-Indoor gathering limit: 50 people but social distance from non-household members
-Places operating at 30% occupancy under Phase 1 can move to 60% occupancy 
-Exercise facilities and personal care services (hair, tanning, tattoo, massage, nail, brow, spas) to remain at 30% occupancy
-Fully unenclosed outdoor gatherings of up to 250 people are permitted
-Leisure travel should be avoided but may resume under general guidance
-All vulnerable individuals should continue to shelter in place
BUSINESS GUIDELINES
-Common areas where people can congregate must remain closed
-Employees/customers have responsibility to self-quarantine if they think they may be sick
-Teleworking is encouraged
-All surfaces touched by customers must be disinfected by EPA-approved disinfectant every 15 minutes to 2 hours 
-Employees required to go to work should perform daily health work 
-All employees must wash hands throughout the day and use hand sanitizer and social distance from other employees
-Businesses must make hand sanitizer available to employees and patrons (hand sanitizer must be 60% ethanol and 70% isopropanol 
-Downtime should be given between shifts and after closing for cleaning 
-Employees must post signs about how to stop spread of COVID-19, hand hygiene, and wear a face covering  Phase Level: 2, Phase Details Source information: https://governor.delaware.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/24/2020/06/Delaware-Economic-Reopening-PHASE-2.pdf

Policy_Details: The new order clarifies that generally all businesses that are within the counties that have been moved to the low risk phase are operating if they can meet and adhere to the specific guidelines. For clarity, the order states symptom checking in public and business interactions should happen when feasible. The guidance for K-12 education addresses the resumption of school activities, including sports, under jurisdiction of district and school authorities in adherence to indoor and outdoor guidelines. Regarding higher education, campuses may be open for in-person classes with increased cleaning and hygiene regimen.   Source information: https://coronavirus.utah.gov/governor-issues-executive-order-releasing-updated-guidelines-for-low-risk-phase-in-the-utah-leads-together-plan/

Policy_Details: Six foot physical distancing requirements for staff, volunteers, and worshippers for services and activities. Offer more protected areas for more vulnerable people and offer them separate areas of entry and exit. Limit the number of people in the service. Recommend worshippers refrain from hugging, handshaking, and other physical contact. Regularly clean and disinfect the facility. Encourage anyone who enters the place of worship to wash hands or use hand sanitizer prior to entry. Ask all staff, volunteers, and worshippers to self monitor for fever or symptoms of COVID-19.   Source information: https://rebound.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/stage1-protocols-worship.pdf

Policy_Details: On 9/30 amended Safer at Home order issued by Scott Harris, State Health Officer (previous order was set to expire 10/2, only change is for HOSPITALS AND NURSING HOMES- Subject to restrictions, patients and residents will be allowed visits from one caregiver or one visitor at a time):
WHAT’S STAYING THE SAME:
Exception remains allowed to face covering order: Any person who cannot wear a facial covering because he or she is actively providing or obtaining access to religious worship, though wearing a face covering is strongly encouraged. 
Guidelines for houses of worship/religious gatherings remain separate from prohibition on nonwork gatherings in order https://alabamapublichealth.gov/covid19/assets/cov-sah-worship.pdf.    Source information: https://governor.alabama.gov/assets/2020/09/GKI-0040-2020-Health-Order-Update-Nov-8-Horizontal-2.pdf,https://governor.alabama.gov/assets/2020/09/Safer-at-Home-Order-Final-9.29.2020.pdf

Policy_Details: Currently open: Grocery stores, pharmacies, banks and credit unions, and gas stations are all open.
Restaurants are open for take-out service only.
Stand alone retail operations are open provided they meet required safety and physical distancing guidelines. Indoor and outdoor malls are closed.
Local outdoor recreation activities are open, including many state parks.
Non-emergency medical care, dentist offices and veterinary care are open and operating, provided they meet required safety guidelines.
Local cultural, civic and faith gatherings are allowed for up to 25 people provided physical distancing can be in place.
Local social gatherings over 10 people are prohibited and those under 10 people must use physical distancing.
Personal care services such as salons and barbers, as well as gyms, are closed.
Child care is open under certain restrictions, with priority placements for children of health care workers, first responders, and frontline workers.
Public transit is open under certain restrictions, and must be sanitized often and enforce 3 feet of space between passengers.
Overnight camps are not permitted. Day camps are open with restrictions, including maximum stable groups of 10 or fewer children.
For summer school, limited in-person, small group instruction and/or summer programming is allowed, with certain restrictions.
 Phase Level: 1, Phase Details Source information: https://govstatus.egov.com/reopening-oregon#phase1

Gatherings limited to 10 indoors (with social distancing of 6 feet, or with face coverings required when 6 feet is not possible) and 20 outdoors (with social distancing 6 feet, or with face coverings required when 6 ft is not possible).  
All businesses should be following relevant guidelines in these counties such as employee screening/reporting daily, social distancing, cleaning, and face coverings when 6 ft not possible.   Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1507.pdf

Policy_Details: The new order clarifies that generally all businesses that are within the counties that have been moved to the low risk phase are operating if they can meet and adhere to the specific guidelines. Regarding higher education, campuses may be open for in-person classes with increased cleaning and hygiene regimen.   Source information: https://coronavirus.utah.gov/governor-issues-executive-order-releasing-updated-guidelines-for-low-risk-phase-in-the-utah-leads-together-plan/

risk.    Source information: https://publications.tnsosfiles.com/pub/execorders/exec-orders-lee55.pdf

Policy_Details: New Mexico's stay at home restrictions were modified on April 30, with an extension of the state's stay-at-home order in place until May 15.
New Mexicans must remain home except for outings essential for health, safety and welfare, especially elderly and vulnerable individuals. If you must leave home, gatherings of more than five people remain prohibited and 6 feet of physical distance from others must be maintained.
Large retailers like big-box stores and grocery stores will continue operating at 20 percent capacity as determined by fire code.
Locations and services where high-intensity contact is unavoidable – such as gyms – will remain temporarily closed. Limited in-person operations for those types of businesses could be included in the next modification of the public health order, as soon as early June, depending on New Mexico’s rate of COVID-19 transmission, testing capacity and other gating criteria.
WHAT WILL CHANGE BEGINNING MAY 16:
Additional state parks and certain outdoor recreation guides with COVID-Safe Practices;
Masks will be required of everyone in public places, with exceptions for eating, drinking and exercising and medical requirements.   Source information: https://cv.nmhealth.org/2020/05/13/stay-at-home-order-extended/

Policy_Details: Phased approach that allows Virginia K-12 schools to slowly open in person classes in summer and upcoming school year
Phase one: Special education programs and child care for working families
Phase two: Phase one plus preschool through third grade students, English learners, and summer camps in school buildings
Phase three: All students may receive in person instruction as can be accommodated with strict social distancing measures that may blend in person and remote learning 
Beyond phase three: Divisions will resume "new-normal" operations under future guidance Phase Level: 2, Phase Details Source information: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/newsroom/all-releases/2020/june/headline-857292-en.html

Policy_Details: Gov. John Bel Edwards' Proclamation 89 JBE 2020 on 7/11: ordered a mandatory mask requirement for Louisiana as well as limited crowd sizes to 50 in both indoor spaces and outdoor spaces where 6 ft social distancing is not possible: all individuals to wear face coverings when inside of commercial establishments or other buildings or spaces open to the public, both indoors and outdoors, including public transportation.  Businesses and organizations must require persons entering to be wearing a face covering unless exceptions apply.  
The statewide mask mandate applies to all 64 parishes in Louisiana. However, parishes with a COVID-19 incidence of fewer than 100 cases per 100,000 people for the most recent two-week period for which data is available could choose to opt out of the mandate. Parish presidents do not have to opt out and may choose to keep a mask mandate in place. Currently, only three parishes in Louisiana do not exceed this standard, which will be updated every other week by the Louisiana Department of Health: Grant, Red River and West Feliciana.
The order requires face coverings for everyone ages 8 and older except for the following:
Anyone who has a medical condition that prevents the wearing of a face covering
Anyone who is consuming a drink or food
Anyone who is trying to communicate with a person who is hearing impaired
Anyone who is giving a speech for broadcast or to an audience
Anyone temporarily removing his or her face covering for identification purposes
Anyone who is a resident of a parish without a high COVID incidence that has opted out of the masking mandate
Masks are strongly recommended for children ages 2 to 7.The statewide mask mandate applies to all 64 parishes in Louisiana. However, parishes with a COVID-19 incidence of fewer than 100 cases per 100,000 people for the most recent two-week period for which data is available could choose to opt out of the mandate. Parish presidents do not have to opt out and may choose to keep a mask mandate in place. Currently, only three parishes in Louisiana do not exceed this standard, which will be updated every other week by the Louisiana Department of Health: Grant, Red River and West Feliciana.
The order requires face coverings for everyone ages 8 and older except for the following:
Anyone who has a medical condition that prevents the wearing of a face covering
Anyone who is consuming a drink or food
Anyone who is trying to communicate with a person who is hearing impaired
Anyone who is giving a speech for broadcast or to an audience
Anyone temporarily removing his or her face covering for identification purposes
Anyone who is a resident of a parish without a high COVID incidence that has opted out of the masking mandate
Masks are strongly recommended for children ages 2 to 7.   Source information: https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/89-JBE-2020.pdf

Policy_Details: This is NOT an SIP/SAH.  It is a Public Health Disaster Emergency Proclamation

"Today, [5/13/20] Governor Reynolds signed a new proclamation continuing the Public Health Disaster Emergency. The proclamation permits salons, barbershops, and massage and tattoo establishments to reopen throughout Iowa in a limited fashion with appropriate public health measures in place. It also permits restaurants (but not bars), fitness centers, libraries, and race tracks to reopen in the 22 counties where they have remained closed. These changes are effective at 5:00 a.m. on Friday, May 15.

The proclamation continues the other ongoing closures and public health measures, including the prohibition on social, community, recreational, leisure, and sporting gatherings and events of more than 10 people, until 11:59 p.m. on May 27, 2020."    Source information: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.05.13.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery

Policy_Details: *Georgia does not have phase numbers associated with restrictions/orders. Governor Brian Kemp signed two orders on July 31st: one to extend the public health state of emergency related to COVID-19 (set to expire August 11, extended 30 days to September 11) to and the other to extend/amend (with no major changes) the Empowering a Healthy Georgia order for another two weeks since the most recent order on July 15th that expired at the end of July . The order is comprehensive and outlines the restrictions/reopening of different business types as well as limits on gatherings and requirements for businesses. Local governments in Georgia cannot mandate face coverings, as noted in the previous order.    Source information: https://gov.georgia.gov/executive-action/executive-orders/2020-executive-orders

Policy_Details: New Mexico's stay at home restrictions were modified on April 30, with an extension of the state's stay-at-home order in place until May 15.

New Mexicans must remain home except for outings essential for health, safety and welfare, especially elderly and vulnerable individuals. If you must leave home, gatherings of more than five people remain prohibited and 6 feet of physical distance from others must be maintained.
Large retailers like big-box stores and grocery stores will continue operating at 20 percent capacity as determined by fire code.
Locations and services where high-intensity contact is unavoidable – such as dine-in service at restaurants and bars – will remain temporarily closed. Limited in-person operations for those types of businesses could be included in the next modification of the public health order, as soon as early June, depending on New Mexico’s rate of COVID-19 transmission, testing capacity and other gating criteria.   Source information: https://cv.nmhealth.org/2020/05/13/stay-at-home-order-extended/

Policy_Details:  Salons As of May 4th, beauty/nail salons, barber shops, massage therapy services, and tattoo parlors/studios in the above LHDs will be permitted to open. These establishments will be added to the list of gatherings subject to the 10-person rule. The new DHM will require both workers and patrons of these establishments to wear masks. For districts other than those listed above, these establishments will remain closed past May 3rd. • Restaurants As of May 4th, restaurants will be allowed to serve dine-in customers if all of the following conditions are met: The restaurant limits seating to 50% of the rated occupancy maximum at all times. The restaurant seats parties at least six feet apart. All dining parties are restricted to no more than six persons (groups larger than six will need to sit at separate tables). Self-serve buffets and salad bars are prohibited. Restaurant staff must serve food directly to customers or implement buffet orders from the customer table. No customer self-service will be allowed. Bar seating is not permitted. Patrons may only consume alcohol on the premises if also consuming a meal. Bars that do not serve food will remain limited to carry-out sales and delivery only. For districts other than those listed above, restaurants will remain limited to delivery, drive-thru, or carryout past May 3rd. • Childcare Facilities As of May 4th, childcare facilities will be permitted to have up to 15 kids per room/space. All other state provisions, statutes, and regulations (including child-to-staff ratios) still apply. For districts other than those listed above, childcares will remain restricted to 10 children per room/space. • Other Establishments Bars, gentlemen’s clubs, bottle clubs, indoor movie theaters, indoor theaters/playhouses will remain closed statewide until May 31st, though the State may revise the DHM prior to that date.   Source information: https://governor.nebraska.gov/press/gov-ricketts-announces-upcoming-changes-directed-health-measures-deploys-additional-resources

Policy_Details: All travelers: Complete a Travel Declaration Form and Self-Isolation Plan, All travelers with negative results must follow strict social distancing for 5 days.
Nonresident travelers: Test 72 hours before departure. If still awaiting results by arrival time, self-quarantine at their own expense while awaiting results. Upon arrival without a pre-test, travelers must pay for testing and quarantine while awaiting results.
Alaska resident travelers: Test 72 hours prior to departure. The 14-day quarantine option is available. 
Critical infrastructure employees: no longer be able to use state-funded testing at airports. Critical infrastructure organizations must provide employees with a letter stating they are traveling for work purposes.    Source information: https://covid19.alaska.gov/health-mandates/

Policy_Details: " Salons
As of May 4th, beauty/nail salons, barber shops, massage therapy services, and tattoo parlors/studios in the above LHDs will be permitted to open.  These establishments will be added to the list of gatherings subject to the 10-person rule.
The new DHM will require both workers and patrons of these establishments to wear masks.
For districts other than those listed above, these establishments will remain closed past May 3rd.
•       Restaurants
As of May 4th, restaurants will be allowed to serve dine-in customers if all of the following conditions are met:
   The restaurant limits seating to 50% of the rated occupancy maximum at all times.
   The restaurant seats parties at least six feet apart.
   All dining parties are restricted to no more than six persons (groups larger than six will need to sit at separate tables).
   Self-serve buffets and salad bars are prohibited.  Restaurant staff must serve food directly to customers or implement buffet orders from the customer table.  No customer self-service will be allowed.
   Bar seating is not permitted.
   Patrons may only consume alcohol on the premises if also consuming a meal.
Bars that do not serve food will remain limited to carry-out sales and delivery only.
For districts other than those listed above, restaurants will remain limited to delivery, drive-thru, or carryout past May 3rd.

•       Childcare Facilities
 As of May 4th, childcare facilities will be permitted to have up to 15 kids per room/space.
    All other state provisions, statutes, and regulations (including child-to-staff ratios) still apply.
    For districts other than those listed above, childcares will remain restricted to 10 children per room/space.

•       Other Establishments
Bars, gentlemen’s clubs, bottle clubs, indoor movie theaters, indoor theaters/playhouses will remain closed statewide until May 31st, though the State may revise the DHM prior to that date."   Source information: https://governor.nebraska.gov/press/gov-ricketts-announces-upcoming-changes-directed-health-measures-deploys-additional-resources

Policy_Details: Governor Northam issued EO 65 easing certain temporary restrictions on businesses
Beauty salons, barbershops, spas, massage centers, tanning salons, tattoo shops, and any other location where personal care or personal grooming services are performed may continue to operate
Occupancy must not exceed 50% and 6 ft between work stations and no more than two appointments per service provider at a time
Employees must wear face coverings
Provide face coverings for clients or ask clients bring their own which they must wear during service
Cleaning and disinfection must be conducted every 60 minutes 
If a business can't adhere, it must close Phase Level: 2, Phase Details Source information: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-65-and-Order-Of-Public-Health-Emergency-Six---AMENDED---Phase-Two-Easing-of-Certain-Temporary-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf

Policy_Details: Arkansas Department of Health Directive related to Governor Asa Hutchinson Executive Order 20-25 (amending EO 20-03): Indoor venues such as theaters, arenas, stadiums, and auction houses that are designed for large groups may reopen on a limited basis for audiences of fewer than 50 and that requires strict social distance among performers, contestants, and members of the audience.  
 Phase Level: 1, Phase Details Source information: https://governor.arkansas.gov/news-media/press-releases/governor-announces-theaters-lecture-halls-other-large-venues-okayed-for-lim, https://governor.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/executiveOrders/EO_20-25._._.pdf

Policy_Details: All Non-Essential Businesses must follow gathering limit, social distancing, and mask requirements. Gyms and other fitness/health centers are restricted to the greater of 50 people or 75% of rated capacity. Door-to-door sales activities are prohibited.   Source information: https://lincoln.ne.gov/city/covid19/pdf/directed-health-measures-2020-09.pdf

Policy_Details: Close contact personal care services include, but are not limited to the following: salons, barber shops, spas, massage parlors, personal care and personal grooming facilities, body art and tattoo services, and tanning salons. Maximum capacity is one (1) client at a time per technician. There shall be a minimum of six (6) feet between chairs, booths, manicure stations, pedicure stations, etc.; this distancing shall apply to vertical, horizontal or diagonal directions. Lobby or waiting areas shall be closed, and items such as magazines, popcorn poppers and coffee pots/machines shall be removed. Minimizing person-to-person contact through technology, like mobile or online reservations and contact-less payment, is encouraged. Clients shall wait outside with appropriate social distancing enforced or clients can remain in cars and called into the store when appropriate service is available. Clients should be screened for fever or respiratory symptoms prior to entry into the salon using the screening questions in Governor Reeves' Executive Order 1480. If the owner, manager or beautician can screen patients via phone before booking an appointment, it is encouraged.
Signage must be posted at each entrance stating no customer with a fever or COVID-19 symptoms are allowed in. Business shall be deep cleaned daily. All instruments shall be disinfected after each client and hampers/trash containers shall be cleaned and disinfected daily. All such containers must have a lid. Hand sanitizer shall be placed at all points of entry and exit.   Source information: http://www.hattiesburgms.com/wp-content/uploads/exec_order_2020-22.pdf

Policy_Details: statewide stay at home order lifted by governor. Edwards announced that Louisiana will be in Phase 1 of reopening from May 15 through June 5. Certain nonessential businesses can open with occupancy limits. Employers are encouraged to continue allowing employees to telework whenever possible. Phase Level: 1, Phase Details Source information: https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/58-JBE-2020.pdf

Policy_Details: Six additional counties were identified as hotspots within MS, adding the following counties to the county-specific executive order with tighter social distancing measures to help limit transmission (tighter restrictions than rest of state under "phase" 3, although phases not used to describe reopening in MS). 
Paragraph I of Executive Order 1509 is amended to add Calhoun, Holmes, Lamar, Montgomery, Winston and Yalobusha Counties. For these counties, the statewide Safe Return instituted in Executive Order 1492 as amended and extended by Executive Orders 1496, 1500, 1505, and 1508 shall remain in full force and effect as issued until 8:00 a.m. on Monday, August 3, 2020, subject to the additional limitations and restricts contained in Executive Order 1509.    Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1512.pdf

Policy_Details: Executive Order by Governor Tate Reeves signed on 7/10, but only applying to Claiborne, Desoto, Grenada, Harrison, Hinds, Jackson, Jefferson, Madison, Quitman, Rnakin, Sunflower, Washington, and Wayne Counties. Amends Safe Return EO 1492/1496/1500/1505 for these counties. 
All businesses should be following relevant guidelines in these counties such as employee screening/reporting daily, social distancing, cleaning, and face coverings when 6 ft not possible.
Retail Businesses should also in addition provide employees with face coverings (when they have contact with public, and these to be cleaned/replaced daily), customers must wear face coverings, hand sanitizer must be provided, 6 ft separation must be kept whenever possible, and sanitation of carts/baskets and high touch areas   Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1507.pdf

Policy_Details: "Phase 3 Details
Oklahoma is currently in Phase 3, which began June 1, 2020.

Hair salons, barbershops, spas, nail salons, tattoo parlors, body piercing shops, pet groomers, and similar businesses may now accept walk-ins.

Policy_Details: " Salons
As of May 4th, beauty/nail salons, barber shops, massage therapy services, and tattoo parlors/studios in the above LHDs will be permitted to open.  These establishments will be added to the list of gatherings subject to the 10-person rule.
The new DHM will require both workers and patrons of these establishments to wear masks.
For districts other than those listed above, these establishments will remain closed past May 3rd.
•       Restaurants
As of May 4th, restaurants will be allowed to serve dine-in customers if all of the following conditions are met:
   The restaurant limits seating to 50% of the rated occupancy maximum at all times.
   The restaurant seats parties at least six feet apart.
   All dining parties are restricted to no more than six persons (groups larger than six will need to sit at separate tables).
   Self-serve buffets and salad bars are prohibited.  Restaurant staff must serve food directly to customers or implement buffet orders from the customer table.  No customer self-service will be allowed.
   Bar seating is not permitted.
   Patrons may only consume alcohol on the premises if also consuming a meal.
Bars that do not serve food will remain limited to carry-out sales and delivery only.
For districts other than those listed above, restaurants will remain limited to delivery, drive-thru, or carryout past May 3rd.

•       Childcare Facilities
 As of May 4th, childcare facilities will be permitted to have up to 15 kids per room/space.
    All other state provisions, statutes, and regulations (including child-to-staff ratios) still apply.
    For districts other than those listed above, childcares will remain restricted to 10 children per room/space.

•       Other Establishments
Bars, gentlemen’s clubs, bottle clubs, indoor movie theaters, indoor theaters/playhouses will remain closed statewide until May 31st, though the State may revise the DHM prior to that date."   Source information: https://governor.nebraska.gov/press/gov-ricketts-announces-upcoming-changes-directed-health-measures-deploys-additional-resources

Policy_Details: Governor Polis issued Executive Order D 2020 093 to amend Executive Orders D 2020 011, D 2020 029, D 2020 052, D 2020 084 due to COVID-19 
-Suspend C.R.S. 44-3-103(38) defining premise as distinct and definite location and C.R.S. 44-3-301(3)(a) requiring separate geographical location for each licensed premises, for limited purpose of allowing two or more on-premise liquor licenses operating in accordance with Safer at Home, as amended, to obtain temporary approval from state & local licensing authorities to modify licensed premises to have communal outdoor dining area that is within 1,000 ft of their licensed premises 
-Liquor Enforcement Division takes action within 24 hours of submission for application of temporary modification of license 
-Temporarily suspend enforcement of statutory limitation prohibiting public consumption of alcohol beverages on any public right of way that has been authorized to allow such consumption by ordinance, resolution, or rule adopted by municipality, city and county, or county   Source information: https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20093LiquorLicensingStatutes.pdf

Policy_Details: This is NOT an SIP/SAH.  It is a Public Health Disaster Emergency Proclamation

"Today, [5/13/20] Governor Reynolds signed a new proclamation continuing the Public Health Disaster Emergency. The proclamation permits salons, barbershops, and massage and tattoo establishments to reopen throughout Iowa in a limited fashion with appropriate public health measures in place. It also permits restaurants (but not bars), fitness centers, libraries, and race tracks to reopen in the 22 counties where they have remained closed. These changes are effective at 5:00 a.m. on Friday, May 15.

The proclamation continues the other ongoing closures and public health measures, including the prohibition on social, community, recreational, leisure, and sporting gatherings and events of more than 10 people, until 11:59 p.m. on May 27, 2020."    Source information: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.05.13.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery
