Policy_Details: Governor Carney announced Phase 2 of Delaware's reopening will begin June 15, 2020
INDIVIDUAL GUIDELINES
-Cloth coverings must be worn
-Non-household members must maximize social distancing
-All individuals in public (parks, outdoor recreation areas, shopping, etc) must social distance
-Indoor gathering limit: 50 people but social distance from non-household members
-Places operating at 30% occupancy under Phase 1 can move to 60% occupancy 
-Exercise facilities and personal care services (hair, tanning, tattoo, massage, nail, brow, spas) to remain at 30% occupancy
-Fully unenclosed outdoor gatherings of up to 250 people are permitted
-Leisure travel should be avoided but may resume under general guidance
-All vulnerable individuals should continue to shelter in place
BUSINESS GUIDELINES
-Common areas where people can congregate must remain closed
-Employees/customers have responsibility to self-quarantine if they think they may be sick
-Teleworking is encouraged
-All surfaces touched by customers must be disinfected by EPA-approved disinfectant every 15 minutes to 2 hours 
-Employees required to go to work should perform daily health work 
-All employees must wash hands throughout the day and use hand sanitizer and social distance from other employees
-Businesses must make hand sanitizer available to employees and patrons (hand sanitizer must be 60% ethanol and 70% isopropanol 
-Downtime should be given between shifts and after closing for cleaning 
-Employees must post signs about how to stop spread of COVID-19, hand hygiene, and wear a face covering  Phase Level: 2, Phase Details Source information: https://governor.delaware.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/24/2020/06/Delaware-Economic-Reopening-PHASE-2.pdf

Policy_Details: """The previous statewide Stay-at-Home and mass gatherings orders are
lifted and mass gatherings of more than 10 individuals are prohibited.
[...]

Industries or functions that are already in operation pursuant to KEFF
may continue to function while, if possible, avoiding gatherings of more
than 10 individuals where social distancing measures are difficult to
maintain.

Any local government that decides to impose equal or more stringent
restrictions during this phase is permitted to do so, except with regards
to essential functions in KEFF.
Any federal restrictions imposed and still in effect must be followed."" (p.9 of pdf in Source)"   Source information: https://covid.ks.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Reopen-Kansas-Framework-v5-1.pdf

Policy_Details: New Mexico's stay at home restrictions were modified on April 30, with an extension of the state's stay-at-home order in place until May 15. New Mexicans must remain home except for outings essential for health, safety and welfare, especially elderly and vulnerable individuals. If you must leave home, gatherings of more than five people remain prohibited and 6 feet of physical distance from others must be maintained. Large retailers like big-box stores and grocery stores will continue operating at 20 percent capacity as determined by fire code. Locations and services where high-intensity contact is unavoidable – such as gyms, salons and dine-in service at restaurants and bars – will remain temporarily closed. Limited in-person operations for those types of businesses could be included in the next modification of the public health order, as soon as early June, depending on New Mexico’s rate of COVID-19 transmission, testing capacity and other gating criteria. Other high-intensity contact services that must remain closed include indoor malls, massage and tattoo parlors, theaters, casinos. 14-day quarantine order remains in place for out-of-state airport arrivals. Vacation rentals prohibited to out-of-state residents. Visits to long-term care and other congregate care facilities remain restricted. WHAT WILL CHANGE BEGINNING MAY 16: All retailers may operate according to COVID-Safe Practices (“CSPs”) at 25 percent fire code occupancy (a “retailer” is any business that sells goods directly to the ultimate consumer or end-users and does not include wholesalers or suppliers, not does it include entertainment venues such as movie theaters, concert halls, or amusement parks); Non-essential businesses (other than retailers; such as office spaces, call centers) generally may operate according to CSPs at up to 25 percent of pre-crisis staffing levels. All employees should continue to work from home wherever possible; Houses of worship may operate at 10 percent occupancy; Additional state parks and certain outdoor recreation guides with COVID-Safe Practices; Masks will be required of everyone in public places, with exceptions for eating, drinking and exercising and medical requirements.   Source information: https://cv.nmhealth.org/2020/05/13/stay-at-home-order-extended/

Policy_Details: Executive Order by Governor Tate Reeves signed on 7/10, but only applying to Claiborne, Desoto, Grenada, Harrison, Hinds, Jackson, Jefferson, Madison, Quitman, Rnakin, Sunflower, Washington, and Wayne Counties. Amends Safe Return EO 1492/1496/1500/1505 for these counties. 
All businesses should be following relevant guidelines in these counties such as employee screening/reporting daily, social distancing, cleaning, and face coverings when 6 ft not possible.
Retail Businesses should also in addition provide employees with face coverings (when they have contact with public, and these to be cleaned/replaced daily), customers must wear face coverings, hand sanitizer must be provided, 6 ft separation must be kept whenever possible, and sanitation of carts/baskets and high touch areas   Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1507.pdf

Policy_Details: Edwards announced that Louisiana will be in Phase 1 of reopening from May 15 through June 5. The stay-at-home order will lift, though high-risk individuals are encouraged to stay home. All individuals must wear face coverings, practice good hygiene and maintain six feet of distance from non-household members. Certain nonessential businesses can open with occupancy limits. Employers are encouraged to continue allowing employees to telework whenever possible.
In Phase 1, the following businesses can open at 25% capacity with sanitation protocols and spacing for physical distancing: gyms, fitness centers, theaters, places of worship, barber shops, nail salons, hair salons, bars serving food, casinos and video poker, museums, zoos and aquariums. Massage parlors, bars without food permits, tattoo parlors, amusement parks, contact sports, playgrounds, theme parks, adult entertainment venues and other similar businesses will remain closed. Phase Level: 1, Phase Details Source information: https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/58-JBE-2020.pdf

Policy_Details: Executive Order 54 by Governor Bill Lee signed 7/3 regarding face coverings: all persons encouraged to wear face coverings in public places.
Further, county mayors in the 89 counties that do not have county health departments have authority to issue orders requiring face coverings so long as they do not require face coverings to be worn while driving (unless for hire), by someone 12 years or younger, those with relevant breathing/health conditions, those unable to remove face coverings without assistance, while eating or drinking, while outdoors unless 6 ft distance not possible, while social distance is kept, when face covering poses security or safety risk, while in a Houses of Worship, or while in a voting site.    Source information: https://publications.tnsosfiles.com/pub/execorders/exec-orders-lee54.pdf

Policy_Details: Gov. John Bel Edwards' Proclamation 89 JBE 2020 on 7/11:  ordered a mandatory mask requirement for Louisiana as well as limited crowd sizes to 50 in both indoor spaces and outdoor spaces where 6 ft social distancing is not possible: all individuals to wear face coverings when inside of commercial establishments or other buildings or spaces open to the public, both indoors and outdoors, including public transportation.  Businesses and organizations must require persons entering to be wearing a face covering unless exceptions apply.  While masks are strongly recommended for children ages 2 to 7, they are not required for those 7 and under. Some counties are eligble to opt out of the mask requirement.    Source information: https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/89-JBE-2020.pdf

Policy_Details: Executive Order 1522 by Governor Tate Reeves - amending previous orders (including 1492) and extending restrictions to 9/30.  Public/private group gatherings where social distancing not possible limited to 10 people indoors and 50 outdoors. Group gatherings where 6 ft social distancing is possible limited to 20 people indoors and 100 outdoors. (more restrictive than in May order, where limit was without social distancing 20 indoors/50 outdoors and with social distancing 50 indoors/100 outdoors).
Amending Executive Order 1480: Gyms now allowed to be open 24 hours per day (previously had to close by 10 pm) and 75% capacity max allowed (up from 30%).    Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1522.pdf

Policy_Details: 25% indoor & outdoor occupancy capacity, 250 persons max, 6 ft social distance, masks strongly recommended for workers & attendees  Phase Level: 2, Phase Details Source information: https://mn.gov/covid19/for-minnesotans/stay-safe-mn/stay-safe-plan.jsp

Policy_Details: Every individual age 5 and older in Wisconsin must wear a face covering if indoors or in an enclosed space, and if other individuals who do not share living space are present. An "enclosed space" is defined as confined space open to members of the public, including outdoor restaurants and parks. A "face covering" is defined as a material or piece of cloth that completely covers the nose and mouth. Exceptions are included for individuals who are consuming food or beverage; communicating with those hard of hearing; accessing services like dental work where masks must be removed; sleeping; swimming or lifeguarding; presenting to an audience who are physically distanced and wearing masks; engaging in work deemed by government safety guidelines where face coverings pose a personal risk; confirming their identity when accessing financial institutions; present where state or federal law or regulations prohibit face coverings; as well as those individuals who are under the age of 2; have trouble breathing; incapacitated in some manner; incarcerated. Wisconsin State Legislature and Wisconsin Supreme Court facilities are also exempt. Violators are subject to a fine of not more than $200.   Source information: https://evers.wi.gov/Documents/COVID19/EmO01-SeptFaceCoverings.pdf

Policy_Details: Executive Order by Governor Tate Reeves signed on 7/10, but only applying to Claiborne, Desoto, Grenada, Harrison, Hinds, Jackson, Jefferson, Madison, Quitman, Rnakin, Sunflower, Washington, and Wayne Counties. Amends Safe Return EO 1492/1496/1500/1505 for these counties. 
Gatherings limited to 10 indoors (with social distancing of 6 feet, or with face coverings required when 6 feet is not possible) and 20 outdoors (with social distancing 6 feet, or with face coverings required when 6 ft is not possible).  
All businesses should be following relevant guidelines in these counties such as employee screening/reporting daily, social distancing, cleaning, and face coverings when 6 ft not possible.   Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1507.pdf

Policy_Details: Gatherings (planned or spontaneous event, public or private, indoor or outdoor) of more than 50 people are prohibited 
Hotels/motels for lodging purposes, livestock auctions, groups of workers being transported for jobs, government business/facilities, relief facilities, residential buildings, grocery stores, truck stops, retail/business establishments, healthcare facilities, alcohol and drug treatment centers, long term care/assisted living facilities, religious or faith based organizations, funeral homes, parades are exempt from this order
Events not specifically identified by name or type within order may allow indoor and outdoor gatherings of more than 50 people but no more than 250 people (rodeos, speedway motor races, outdoor concerts, sporting events, fairs, track/field races, farmer's markets, firework shows, weddings)
Groups of attendees must be limited to 6 
6ft distance between individual groups
# of people in confined area must be limited to allow for adequate distancing between households
Close contact between members of different households is prohibited before, during, after event
Staff, host/organizers of event, event participants must be screened for symptoms of COVID-19 prior to event 
Entire event facility shall be cleaned thoroughly
Staff who come within 6 ft of event attendees must wear face covering
Face coverings must be worn by individual groups if 6 ft is not possible 
Event shall not take place without appropriate PPE for staff
Encourage contactless and non-signature payment
Signage reminding attendees not to enter if they have symptoms of COVID-19
Participants in sporting events shall not congregate in groups larger than 50 people
 Phase Level: 2, Phase Details Source information: https://covid19.wyo.gov/governors-orders

Policy_Details: On 7/23 Gov. John Bel Edwards signed Proclamation 96 JBE 2020 extending Phase 2 which also included a mask mandate (face covering must be worn by all, with exceptions including while consuming food/drink, when inside a commercial establishment or any other building or space open to the public, whether indoor or outdoor)
All restaurants, cafes, and coffee shops shall be allowed to continue drive-up or curb-side delivery service.
b) All restaurants, cafes, and coffee shops shall be allowed to begin dine in service under the following conditions:
i) No establishment shall exceed 50% of the total occupancy as determined by the State Fire Marshal.
ii) Waiting areas shall be closed. Members of the public should be required to make reservations or to wait outside, while maintaining moderate social distancing, or in vehicles. 

No bar, with or without a food service permit from the Louisiana Department of Health, shall allow for on premises consumption of any food or drinks. However, any bar shall be allowed to provide for takeout through drive-thru or curbside delivery, including alcoholic beverages.   Source information: https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/96-JBE-2020-State-of-Emergency-COVID-19-Resilient-Louisiana-Phase-2.pdf

Policy_Details: Governor Polis issued a revised version of Safer at Home, and in the Vast, Great Outdoors
-Houses of worship are encouraged to implement electronic platforms to conduct services whenever possible or to conduct more frequent services of 10 people or less
-Houses of worship may open to 50% occupancy and not to exceed 50 people indoors
-Outdoor worship services can attain approval for maximum numbers of individuals and must maintain 6 ft apart from non-household members
-Face coverings are encouraged to be worn by staff, volunteers, and congregants, unless the person is under 2 years old, has trouble breathing, or those who can't remove a mask without assistance
-Houses of worship must follow guidelines for cleaning and disinfecting their buildings before, during, and after worship 
-   Source information: https://covid19.colorado.gov/covid-19-in-colorado/public-health-executive-orders-resource

Policy_Details: Executive Order by Governor Tate Reeves signed on 7/10, but only applying to Claiborne, Desoto, Grenada, Harrison, Hinds, Jackson, Jefferson, Madison, Quitman, Rnakin, Sunflower, Washington, and Wayne Counties. Amends Safe Return EO 1492/1496/1500/1505 for these counties. 
All businesses should be following relevant guidelines in these counties such as employee screening/reporting daily, social distancing, cleaning, and face coverings when 6 ft not possible.   Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1507.pdf

Policy_Details: Six additional counties were identified as hotspots within MS, adding the following counties to the county-specific executive order with tighter social distancing measures to help limit transmission (tighter restrictions than rest of state under "phase" 3, although phases not used to describe reopening in MS). 
Paragraph I of Executive Order 1509 is amended to add Calhoun, Holmes, Lamar, Montgomery, Winston and Yalobusha Counties. For these counties, the statewide Safe Return instituted in Executive Order 1492 as amended and extended by Executive Orders 1496, 1500, 1505, and 1508 shall remain in full force and effect as issued until 8:00 a.m. on Monday, August 3, 2020, subject to the additional limitations and restricts contained in Executive Order 1509.    Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1512.pdf

Policy_Details: Executive Order by Governor Tate Reeves signed on 7/10, but only applying to Claiborne, Desoto, Grenada, Harrison, Hinds, Jackson, Jefferson, Madison, Quitman, Rnakin, Sunflower, Washington, and Wayne Counties. Amends Safe Return EO 1492/1496/1500/1505 for these counties.

Policy_Details: On 9/30 amended Safer at Home order issued by Scott Harris, State Health Officer (previous order was set to expire 10/2, only change is for HOSPITALS AND NURSING HOMES- Subject to restrictions, patients and residents will be allowed visits from one caregiver or one visitor at a time):
WHAT’S STAYING THE SAME:
ATHLETIC ACTIVITIES
Allowed subject to social-distancing and sanitation rules and guidelines
SENIOR CITIZEN CENTERS
Regular programming still suspended except meals still available through curbside pick-up or delivery
NON-WORK GATHERINGS
Still required to maintain 6 feet of distance between persons not from same household
ATHLETIC FACILITIES (SUCH AS FITNESS CENTERS AND COMMERCIAL GYMS)
Athletic facilities may open subject to social-distancing and sanitation rules and guidelines
BEACHES
Open with no limit on gatherings. Must maintain 6 feet of separation   Source information: https://governor.alabama.gov/assets/2020/09/GKI-0040-2020-Health-Order-Update-Nov-8-Horizontal-2.pdf,https://governor.alabama.gov/assets/2020/09/Safer-at-Home-Order-Final-9.29.2020.pdf

Policy_Details: On 7/23 Gov. John Bel Edwards signed Proclamation 96 JBE 2020 extending Phase 2 which also included a mask mandate (face covering must be worn by all, with exceptions, when inside a commercial establishment or any other building or space open to the public, whether indoor or outdoor)
No bar, with or without a food service permit from the Louisiana Department of Health, shall allow for on premises consumption of any food or drinks. However, any bar shall be allowed to provide for takeout through drive-thru or curbside delivery, including alcoholic beverages

Places of public amusement (including but not limited to, locations with amusement rides, carnivals, amusement parks, splash pads, water parks, trampoline parks, arcades, fairs and festivals, children's play centers, indoor playgrounds, theme parks, concert and music halls) to remain closed unless the business submits a reopening plan that must be approved by the State Fire Marshal in consultation with the State Department of Health- occupancy will not exceed 50% in these approved plans (or guidance for opening in phase 3). 

Shopping malls may reopen at no more than 50% of the total occupancy as determined by the State Fire Marshal.
b) Any store or business establishment in a shopping mall may reopen at no more than 50% of the total occupancy as determined by the State Fire Marshal, counting both the number of employees and members of the public present in the building at one time.
c) Mall food courts may open in line with the restaurant guidance 

Casinos, Racetracks, and Video Poker Establishments:
a) No establishment shall exceed 50% of the total occupancy as determined by the State Fire Marshal.
b) No more than 75% of gaming positions shall be in use at anyone time and all utilized gaming positions shall be at least 6 feet apart from one another, unless separated by physical barriers.
c) All establishments shall be required to have approved reopening plans from the Louisiana Gaming Control Board prior to reopening. Further, any plan to use physical barriers needs to be approved by the Louisiana Gaming Control Board.
d) All racetracks shall be required to have an approved reopening plan from the Louisiana Racing Commission prior to reopening.
e) Lobbies or other areas where members of the public may congregate (except for bathrooms) shall be closed to the public. Members of the public should be required to wait outside, while maintaining social distancing, or in vehicles.    Source information: https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/96-JBE-2020-State-of-Emergency-COVID-19-Resilient-Louisiana-Phase-2.pdf

Policy_Details: All vulnerable Idahoans should continue to self-isolate. Gatherings, both public and private, of less than 10 people, where appropriate physical distancing and precautionary measures are observed can occur. Hair salons open if ability to meet business protocols. Indoor gyms and recreation facilities can open if ability to meet business protocols. Restaurant dining rooms can open once their plans have been submitted for approval by local public health districts. Nightclubs remain closed. Nightclubs should develop plans for reopening as a bar in Stage 3 with ability to meet business protocols and without close contact activities such as dancing. Bars remain closed. Bars should develop plans for reopening and ability to meet business protocols in order to open in stage 3. Large venues (e.g., movie theaters, and sporting venues) are closed. Phase Level: 2, Phase Details Source information: https://coronavirus.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/stay-healthy-order-stage2.pdf

Policy_Details: restaurant, food courts, cafes, coffeehouses, bars, taverns, brew pubs, breweries, microbreweries, distillery pubs, wineries, tasting rooms, special licensees, clubs, cigar brs, and other places of public accommodation offering food, beverages or alcoholic beverages, indoors and outdoors may provide services. conditions: all patrons must be seated, tables limited to 6 people, tables at least 6 ft apart, signage must be posted reminding people to stand 6 ft apart, staff shall wear face masks.....   Source information: https://covid19.wyo.gov/governors-orders

Policy_Details: New Mexico Department of Health Public Health Order, amending/extending set of PH orders most recently amended July 13 with no major changes:  Retail spaces may still not exceed 25% capacity and spaces may still not allow persons without face coverings to enter without exemption from healthcare provider (no new change).  Other businesses that are not essential or designated otherwise in the order may not exceed 25% capacity.  Close contact (personal care and fitness studios/gyms) businesses may continue to operate at 25% capacity.    Source information: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/07.30.20-PHO.pdf

Policy_Details: Governor Roy Cooper signed Executive Order 162 on 8/31 which extends Executive Order 153, which restricts late-night service of alcoholic beverages- restaurants, breweries, wineries, distilleries and other establishments that serve alcohol for on-site consumption must cease alcohol sales and service at 11 p.m. and may not resume them until 7 a.m. Bars that were not open before remain closed, this only applies to establishments already open.    Source information: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO162-Extending-Alcohol-Curfew.pdf

Policy_Details: This is NOT an SIP/SAH. It is a Public Health Disaster Emergency Proclamation "Today, [5/13/20] Governor Reynolds signed a new proclamation continuing the Public Health Disaster Emergency. The proclamation permits salons, barbershops, and massage and tattoo establishments to reopen throughout Iowa in a limited fashion with appropriate public health measures in place. It also permits restaurants (but not bars), fitness centers, libraries, and race tracks to reopen in the 22 counties where they have remained closed. These changes are effective at 5:00 a.m. on Friday, May 15. The proclamation continues the other ongoing closures and public health measures, including the prohibition on social, community, recreational, leisure, and sporting gatherings and events of more than 10 people, until 11:59 p.m. on May 27, 2020."   Source information: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.05.13.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery

For these counties, the statewide Safe Return instituted in Executive Order 1492 as amended and extended by Executive Orders 1496, 1500, 1505, and 1508 shall remain in full force and effect as issued until 8:00 a.m. on Monday, August 3, 2020, subject to the additional limitations and restricts contained in Executive Order 1509.    Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1512.pdf

Policy_Details: *phase 2.5 
Governor Roy Cooper signed Executive Order 163 on 9/1: Revised prohibitions and restrictions that move the state in Safer at Home Phase 2.5 measures.
what changes in this order: 
- Museums and aquariums can open at 50% capacity.
- Fitness and competitive physical activity facilities can open at 30% capacity.
- All employers in North Carolina are strongly encouraged to provide face coverings to their employees.
what remains the same: 
- Bars, nightclubs, movie theaters, amusement parks, dance halls and other entertainment facilities will remain closed.
- Personal care businesses, such as hair salons, nail salons, barber shops and more remain subject to capacity limits and other requirements.
   Source information: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO163-New-Phase-2.5.pdf

Policy_Details: o Restaurants, bars, breweries, distilleries, and casinos can become operational on or after May 4, 2020 under strict physical distancing and reduced capacity protocols in accordance with State guidelines.  These businesses will be required to close their doors and have all patrons out by 11:30 p.m. Breweries and distilleries shall follow existing laws on closing time.  The expansions for delivery and takeout services, as provided both in the March 24 and March 26 Directives, are extended through the end of the emergency.  In addition, restaurants, bars, breweries, distilleries, and casinos that reopen must adhere to the general and specific guidelines provided in Appendix A, attached. Governor Brian Kemp signed two orders on July 31st: one to extend the public health state of emergency related to COVID-19 (set to expire August 11, extended 30 days to September 11) to and the other to extend/amend (with no major changes) the Empowering a Healthy Georgia order for another two weeks since the most recent order on July 15th that expired at the end of July . The order is comprehensive and outlines the restrictions/reopening of different business types as well as limits on gatherings and requirements for businesses. Local governments in Georgia cannot mandate face coverings, as noted in the previous order.    Source information: https://gov.georgia.gov/executive-action/executive-orders/2020-executive-orders

Policy_Details: Six additional counties were identified as hotspots within MS, adding the following counties to the county-specific executive order with tighter social distancing measures to help limit transmission (tighter restrictions than rest of state under "phase" 3, although phases not used to describe reopening in MS).

Policy_Details: Emergency Order 13 by County Administrator: Following the footsteps of its South Florida neighbors, Palm Beach County beaches will be closed starting Friday through Sunday, ahead of the Fourth of July holiday weekend.

All beaches, no matter if they are municipal or private, will be closed. Restaurants and shops inside beach parks will be allowed to operate but must continue to abide by the mask mandate and physical distancing guidelines.

Policy_Details: "During Phase I, we can gradually start to reopen economic and social activity. This will be a deliberate process, and is flexible to adapt to the situation. Some communities may be able to reopen at a faster rate, while others may need to continue restrictions to keep the virus from spreading. During Phase I, we should limit our activity and interactions and continue to maintain social distancing and practice good hygiene to protect our neighbors and ourselves. Citizens who feel sick should stay home! Continue to practice good hygiene, including: Washing hands with soap and water, or using hand sanitizer, especially after touching frequently used items or surfaces; Avoiding touching your face; Sneezing or coughing into a tissue, or the inside of your elbow; and Disinfecting frequently used items and surfaces as much as possible. Avoid socializing in groups that do not readily allow for appropriate physical distancing (receptions, trade shows, etc.). When in public (parks, outdoor recreation spaces, shopping malls, etc.), individuals should maximize physical distance from others. Minimize travel to the extent possible."   Source information: https://governor.mo.gov/sites/gov/files/media/pdf/2020/04/Economic-Reopening-Phase-1.pdf

Policy_Details: Executive Order by Governor Tate Reeves signed on 7/10, but only applying to Claiborne, Desoto, Grenada, Harrison, Hinds, Jackson, Jefferson, Madison, Quitman, Rnakin, Sunflower, Washington, and Wayne Counties. Amends Safe Return EO 1492/1496/1500/1505 for these counties. 
All businesses should be following relevant guidelines in these counties such as employee screening/reporting daily, social distancing, cleaning, and face coverings when 6 ft not possible.
Retail Businesses should also in addition provide employees with face coverings (when they have contact with public, and these to be cleaned/replaced daily), customers must wear face coverings, hand sanitizer must be provided, 6 ft separation must be kept whenever possible, and sanitation of carts/baskets and high touch areas   Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1507.pdf

Policy_Details: On 7/23 Gov. John Bel Edwards signed Proclamation 96 JBE 2020 extending Phase 2 which also included a mask mandate (face covering must be worn by all, with exceptions, when inside a commercial establishment or any other building or space open to the public, whether indoor or outdoor)
Gyms and fitness centers:
a) No establishment shall exceed 50% of the total occupancy as determined by the State Fire Marshal.
b) Waiting rooms, lobbies, or other areas where members of the public may congregate (except for bathrooms) shall be closed to the public. Members of the public should be required to wait outside, while maintaining social distancing, or in vehicles. 

To further prevent the spread of COVID-19, crowd sizes shall be limited to no
more than 50 people in any single indoor space at the same time. Crowd sizes are limited to no more than 50 people in any single outdoor space where individuals will be in close proximity to one another and unable to maintain strict  social distancing of six feet apart from individuals who are not immediate household members.    Source information: https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/96-JBE-2020-State-of-Emergency-COVID-19-Resilient-Louisiana-Phase-2.pdf

Policy_Details: " Salons
As of May 4th, beauty/nail salons, barber shops, massage therapy services, and tattoo parlors/studios in the above LHDs will be permitted to open.  These establishments will be added to the list of gatherings subject to the 10-person rule.
The new DHM will require both workers and patrons of these establishments to wear masks.
For districts other than those listed above, these establishments will remain closed past May 3rd.
•       Restaurants
As of May 4th, restaurants will be allowed to serve dine-in customers if all of the following conditions are met:
   The restaurant limits seating to 50% of the rated occupancy maximum at all times.
   The restaurant seats parties at least six feet apart.
   All dining parties are restricted to no more than six persons (groups larger than six will need to sit at separate tables).
   Self-serve buffets and salad bars are prohibited.  Restaurant staff must serve food directly to customers or implement buffet orders from the customer table.  No customer self-service will be allowed.
   Bar seating is not permitted.
   Patrons may only consume alcohol on the premises if also consuming a meal.
Bars that do not serve food will remain limited to carry-out sales and delivery only.
For districts other than those listed above, restaurants will remain limited to delivery, drive-thru, or carryout past May 3rd.

•       Childcare Facilities
 As of May 4th, childcare facilities will be permitted to have up to 15 kids per room/space.
    All other state provisions, statutes, and regulations (including child-to-staff ratios) still apply.
    For districts other than those listed above, childcares will remain restricted to 10 children per room/space.

•       Other Establishments
Bars, gentlemen’s clubs, bottle clubs, indoor movie theaters, indoor theaters/playhouses will remain closed statewide until May 31st, though the State may revise the DHM prior to that date."   Source information: https://governor.nebraska.gov/press/gov-ricketts-announces-upcoming-changes-directed-health-measures-deploys-additional-resources

Policy_Details: New Mexico Department of Health Public Health Order, amending/extending set of PH orders most recently amended July 13 with no major changes: Mass gatherings of any kind, outdoor and indoor, (5+) remain prohibited (no new change). Close-contact recreational facilities (like indoor movie theaters, museums, amusement parks, casinos, mini golf, aquariums, concert venues, clubs, etc.) remain closed.  Some recreational facilities (like outdoor golf courses, public swimming pools, outdoor tennis courts, summer youth programs, botanical gardens, zoos, etc.) may operate under guidelines, including state parks for day use only and only by NM residents, public swimming pools limited to lane swim and lessons and no spectators for horseracing tracks. Places of lodging no more than 50% capacity.  Close contact (personal care and fitness studios/gyms) businesses may continue to operate at 25% capacity.  (no new major changes, slight amendments to classification of recreational businesses)   Source information: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/07.30.20-PHO.pdf

Policy_Details: Governor Ivey amended Safer at Home Order to reopen some businesses including restaurants, bars, barber shops, salons, and gyms.  Atheltic actitivies with close contact and venues such as night clubs, casinos, arcades, and theaters to be closed.    Source information: https://governor.alabama.gov/newsroom/2020/05/governor-ivey-issues-amended-safer-at-home-order/, https://governor.alabama.gov/assets/2020/05/Safer-at-Home-Order-FINAL-5.8.2020.pdf

Policy_Details: Executive Order by Governor Tate Reeves signed on 7/10, but only applying to Claiborne, Desoto, Grenada, Harrison, Hinds, Jackson, Jefferson, Madison, Quitman, Rnakin, Sunflower, Washington, and Wayne Counties. Amends Safe Return EO 1492/1496/1500/1505 for these counties. 
Gatherings limited to 10 indoors (with social distancing of 6 feet, or with face coverings required when 6 feet is not possible) and 20 outdoors (with social distancing 6 feet, or with face coverings required when 6 ft is not possible).  
All businesses should be following relevant guidelines in these counties such as employee screening/reporting daily, social distancing, cleaning, and face coverings when 6 ft not possible.   Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1507.pdf

Policy_Details: Executive Order by Governor Tate Reeves signed on 7/10, but only applying to Claiborne, Desoto, Grenada, Harrison, Hinds, Jackson, Jefferson, Madison, Quitman, Rnakin, Sunflower, Washington, and Wayne Counties. Amends Safe Return EO 1492/1496/1500/1505 for these counties.

Policy_Details: Executive Order by Governor Tate Reeves signed on 7/10, but only applying to Claiborne, Desoto, Grenada, Harrison, Hinds, Jackson, Jefferson, Madison, Quitman, Rnakin, Sunflower, Washington, and Wayne Counties. Amends Safe Return EO 1492/1496/1500/1505 for these counties. 
All businesses should be following relevant guidelines in these counties such as employee screening/reporting daily, social distancing, cleaning, and face coverings when 6 ft not possible.
Retail Businesses should also in addition provide employees with face coverings (when they have contact with public, and these to be cleaned/replaced daily), customers must wear face coverings, hand sanitizer must be provided, 6 ft separation must be kept whenever possible, and sanitation of carts/baskets and high touch areas   Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1507.pdf

Policy_Details: Six additional counties were identified as hotspots within MS, adding the following counties to the county-specific executive order with tighter social distancing measures to help limit transmission (tighter restrictions than rest of state under "phase" 3, although phases not used to describe reopening in MS).

For these counties, the statewide Safe Return instituted in Executive Order 1492 as amended and extended by Executive Orders 1496, 1500, 1505, and 1508 shall remain in full force and effect as issued until 8:00 a.m. on Monday, August 3, 2020, subject to the additional limitations and restricts contained in Executive Order 1509. Policy_Details: *Georgia does not have phase numbers associated with restrictions/orders. Governor Brian Kemp signed Executive Order on August 15th to extend/amend the Empowering a Healthy Georgia order for another two weeks since the most recent order from the beginning of August that expired August 15th . The order is comprehensive and outlines the restrictions/reopening of different business types as well as limits on gatherings and requirements for businesses. Local governments in Georgia previously could not mandate face coverings, as noted in the previous order, but now are able to on a limited basis require them on government property when threshold met in a county (100+ cases per 100,000 people in previous 14 days). Face coverings are otherwise strongly encouraged.   Source information: https://gov.georgia.gov/executive-action/executive-orders/2020-executive-orders

Policy_Details: *phase 2.5 
Revised prohibitions and restrictions that move the state in Safer at Home Phase 2.5 measures.
what changes in this order: 
- Mass gathering limits will be increased to 25 people indoors and 50 people outdoors.
- Museums and aquariums can open at 50% capacity.
what remains the same: 
- Bars, nightclubs, movie theaters, amusement parks, dance halls and other entertainment facilities will remain closed.
- Large venues remain subject to the mass gathering limits.
- Wedding receptions and other private events remain subject to the mass gathering limits.   Source information: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO163-New-Phase-2.5.pdf

Policy_Details: On Tuesday, May 19, Bexar County Judge Nelson Wolff issued Executive Order NW-08 to supplement the existing Stay Home, Work Safe measures. These additional measures will take effect as of 12:01 a.m. on May 19 and continue through June 4, 2020 unless extended, modified or terminated early by the County Judge, and is consistent with Texas Governor Greg Abbott’s executive order and mandates issued by the City of San Antonio.   Source information: https://www.bexar.org/3234/COVID-19

Policy_Details: Phase 2 of the "Ad Astra" plan. Phase Level: 2, Phase Details: Mass gatherings of more than 15 individuals will be prohibited; All businesses and activities slated to open during Phase 2 will be allowed, with the exception of bars, night clubs and swimming pools. These will be moved to Phase 3; Businesses and activities that will be allowed to open in Phase 2 include: Recreational organized sports facilities, tournaments and practices will be allowed to begin on Friday, May 22, and must adhere to social distancing requirements and follow Parks and Recs guidelines, which can be found on covid.ks.gov; Community Centers will be allowed to open, except for indoor and outdoor swimming pools; Indoor leisure spaces such as arcades, trampoline parks, theaters, museums and bowling allies will be allowed to open on May 22; State-owned-and-operated casinos will be allowed to open once their re-opening plan has been approved by the Kansas Department of Health and Environment; In-person group exercise classes will be allowed to begin with groups of no more than 15 at a time. Locker rooms remain closed except for restroom facilities; Everything opened in Phase 1 and Phase 1.5 remains open pursuant to the restrictions outlined in Executive Order 20-34. Source information: https://governor.kansas.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/EO-20-34-Implementing-Phase-2-Executed.pdf
Summit County Policy End

Policy_Details: On 7/23 Gov. John Bel Edwards signed Proclamation 96 JBE 2020 extending Phase 2 which also included a mask mandate (face covering must be worn by all, with exceptions, when inside a commercial establishment or any other building or space open to the public, whether indoor or outdoor)
Shopping malls may reopen at no more than 50% of the total occupancy as determined by the State Fire Marshal.
b) Any store or business establishment in a shopping mall may reopen at no more than 50% of the total occupancy as determined by the State Fire Marshal, counting both the number of employees and members of the public present in the building at one time.
c) Mall food courts may open in line with the restaurant guidance 
All other businesses or organizations shall be allowed to continue operations, subject to the following conditions:
a) No establishment shall exceed 50% of the total occupancy as determined by the State Fire Marshal.
b) Waiting rooms, lobbies, or other areas where members of the public may congregate (except for bathrooms) shall be closed to the public.
Members of the public should be required to wait outside, while maintaining social distancing, or in vehicles
All beauty shops, salons, and barber shops shall be allowed to operate under
the following conditions:
a) No establishment shall exceed 50% of the total occupancy as determined by the State Fire Marshal.
b) Waiting areas shall be closed. Members of the public should be required to make reservations or to wait outside, while maintaining social distancing, or in vehicles   Source information: https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/96-JBE-2020-State-of-Emergency-COVID-19-Resilient-Louisiana-Phase-2.pdf

Policy_Details: Ends the following restrictions on spectator sports and athletic activities: local education agencies and schools shall, notwithstanding any orders or provisions to the contrary, have the authority to permit, but are not required to permit, school sponsored sporting events and activities, provided that all such activities, including practices and games or competition, must be conducted in a  manner consistent with COVID-19-related guidance and rules adopted by the Tennessee Secondary Schools Athletic Association. Non-school-sponsored athletics, including practices, games, and competition, must be conducted in a manner consistent with guidance from either the Tennessee Economic Recovery Group (i.e., Tennessee Pledge) or Tennessee Secondary Schools Athletic Association. With respect to school-sponsored and other youth athletics, schools, organizers, and facilities shall not permit spectators to attend practices, games, or competition; provided, that game, school, and facility administrators, teachers, athletics officials, coaching and team personnel, parents, grandparents, guardians, or other immediate household members of athletes practicing or competing at the venue on that date, media and athletic scouting personnel attending the event in their professional capacity, and first responders may be present within the facility, but must to the greatest extent practicable comply with applicable health protocols, including maintaining at  least six (6) feet of separation from persons outside their household. Schools, facilities, organizers, and governing bodies may further limit physical capacity as deemed necessary to protect public health. Collegiate and professional sporting events and activities are subject to the rules, protocols, or guidelines of their respective institutions and governing bodies.    Source information: https://publications.tnsosfiles.com/pub/execorders/exec-orders-lee75.pdf

Policy_Details: Executive Order by Governor Tate Reeves signed on 7/10, but only applying to Claiborne, Desoto, Grenada, Harrison, Hinds, Jackson, Jefferson, Madison, Quitman, Rnakin, Sunflower, Washington, and Wayne Counties. Amends Safe Return EO 1492/1496/1500/1505 for these counties.

Policy_Details: On 7/23 Gov. John Bel Edwards signed Proclamation 96 JBE 2020 extending Phase 2 which also included a mask mandate (face covering must be worn by all, with exceptions, when inside a commercial establishment or any other building or space open to the public, whether indoor or outdoor)
Churches and other faith-based organizations:
a) No establishment shall exceed 50% of the total occupancy as determined by the State Fire Marshal.
b) Outdoor services may continue pursuant to the May I, 2020 guidance set forth by the State Fire Marshal.
c) Lobbies or other areas where members of the public may congregate (except for bathrooms) shall be closed to the public.
d) Any church or faith-based organization shall follow the applicable guidance from the State Fire Marshal published at opensafely.la.gov.
e) Church and faith-based services shall not be limited by the crowd size restrictions (no gatherings above 50 does not apply)
(face covering must be worn by all, with exceptions, when inside a commercial establishment or any other building or space open to the public, whether indoor or outdoor)   Source information: https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/96-JBE-2020-State-of-Emergency-COVID-19-Resilient-Louisiana-Phase-2.pdf

Policy_Details: " Salons
As of May 4th, beauty/nail salons, barber shops, massage therapy services, and tattoo parlors/studios in the above LHDs will be permitted to open.  These establishments will be added to the list of gatherings subject to the 10-person rule.
The new DHM will require both workers and patrons of these establishments to wear masks.
For districts other than those listed above, these establishments will remain closed past May 3rd.
•       Restaurants
As of May 4th, restaurants will be allowed to serve dine-in customers if all of the following conditions are met:
   The restaurant limits seating to 50% of the rated occupancy maximum at all times.
   The restaurant seats parties at least six feet apart.
   All dining parties are restricted to no more than six persons (groups larger than six will need to sit at separate tables).
   Self-serve buffets and salad bars are prohibited.  Restaurant staff must serve food directly to customers or implement buffet orders from the customer table.  No customer self-service will be allowed.
   Bar seating is not permitted.
   Patrons may only consume alcohol on the premises if also consuming a meal.
Bars that do not serve food will remain limited to carry-out sales and delivery only.
For districts other than those listed above, restaurants will remain limited to delivery, drive-thru, or carryout past May 3rd.

•       Childcare Facilities
 As of May 4th, childcare facilities will be permitted to have up to 15 kids per room/space.
    All other state provisions, statutes, and regulations (including child-to-staff ratios) still apply.
    For districts other than those listed above, childcares will remain restricted to 10 children per room/space.

•       Other Establishments
Bars, gentlemen’s clubs, bottle clubs, indoor movie theaters, indoor theaters/playhouses will remain closed statewide until May 31st, though the State may revise the DHM prior to that date."   Source information: https://governor.nebraska.gov/press/gov-ricketts-announces-upcoming-changes-directed-health-measures-deploys-additional-resources

Policy_Details: On 9/30 amended Safer at Home order issued by Scott Harris, State Health Officer (previous order was set to expire 10/2, only change is for HOSPITALS AND NURSING HOMES- Subject to restrictions, patients and residents will be allowed visits from one caregiver or one visitor at a time): Facial Covering Requirement effective July 16 remains in effect with no change: requires masks to be worn with exceptions for those 6 and under, anyone when swimming, exercising, eating/drinking, participating in "constitutionally protected activities" (voting, religious worship), for safety/security reasons, for valid medical reasons, when receiving service (i.e. dental), and when unsafe by industry standards.  
WHAT’S STAYING THE SAME:
MASKS IN SCHOOLS
Masks required in schools and colleges, where possible, for employees and students in second grade and above
MASKS
Masks required in public when interacting within 6 feet with people of another household, subject to certain exceptions   Source information: https://governor.alabama.gov/assets/2020/09/GKI-0040-2020-Health-Order-Update-Nov-8-Horizontal-2.pdf,https://governor.alabama.gov/assets/2020/09/Safer-at-Home-Order-Final-9.29.2020.pdf

Policy_Details:  Salons As of May 4th, beauty/nail salons, barber shops, massage therapy services, and tattoo parlors/studios in the above LHDs will be permitted to open. These establishments will be added to the list of gatherings subject to the 10-person rule. The new DHM will require both workers and patrons of these establishments to wear masks. For districts other than those listed above, these establishments will remain closed past May 3rd. • Restaurants As of May 4th, restaurants will be allowed to serve dine-in customers if all of the following conditions are met: The restaurant limits seating to 50% of the rated occupancy maximum at all times. The restaurant seats parties at least six feet apart. All dining parties are restricted to no more than six persons (groups larger than six will need to sit at separate tables). Self-serve buffets and salad bars are prohibited. Restaurant staff must serve food directly to customers or implement buffet orders from the customer table. No customer self-service will be allowed. Bar seating is not permitted. Patrons may only consume alcohol on the premises if also consuming a meal. Bars that do not serve food will remain limited to carry-out sales and delivery only. For districts other than those listed above, restaurants will remain limited to delivery, drive-thru, or carryout past May 3rd. • Childcare Facilities As of May 4th, childcare facilities will be permitted to have up to 15 kids per room/space. All other state provisions, statutes, and regulations (including child-to-staff ratios) still apply. For districts other than those listed above, childcares will remain restricted to 10 children per room/space. • Other Establishments Bars, gentlemen’s clubs, bottle clubs, indoor movie theaters, indoor theaters/playhouses will remain closed statewide until May 31st, though the State may revise the DHM prior to that date.   Source information: https://governor.nebraska.gov/press/gov-ricketts-announces-upcoming-changes-directed-health-measures-deploys-additional-resources

Policy_Details: public parks, fishing, boating, golf open ; playgrounds closed  Phase Level: 1, Phase Details Source information: https://www.cookcountypublichealth.org/communicable-diseases/covid-19/

Policy_Details: New Mexico's stay at home restrictions were modified on April 30, with an extension of the state's stay-at-home order in place until May 15. New Mexicans must remain home except for outings essential for health, safety and welfare, especially elderly and vulnerable individuals. If you must leave home, gatherings of more than five people remain prohibited and 6 feet of physical distance from others must be maintained. Large retailers like big-box stores and grocery stores will continue operating at 20 percent capacity as determined by fire code. Locations and services where high-intensity contact is unavoidable – such as gyms, salons and dine-in service at restaurants and bars – will remain temporarily closed. Limited in-person operations for those types of businesses could be included in the next modification of the public health order, as soon as early June, depending on New Mexico’s rate of COVID-19 transmission, testing capacity and other gating criteria. Other high-intensity contact services that must remain closed include indoor malls, massage and tattoo parlors, theaters, casinos. 14-day quarantine order remains in place for out-of-state airport arrivals. Vacation rentals prohibited to out-of-state residents. Visits to long-term care and other congregate care facilities remain restricted. WHAT WILL CHANGE BEGINNING MAY 16: All retailers may operate according to COVID-Safe Practices (“CSPs”) at 25 percent fire code occupancy (a “retailer” is any business that sells goods directly to the ultimate consumer or end-users and does not include wholesalers or suppliers, not does it include entertainment venues such as movie theaters, concert halls, or amusement parks); Non-essential businesses (other than retailers; such as office spaces, call centers) generally may operate according to CSPs at up to 25 percent of pre-crisis staffing levels. All employees should continue to work from home wherever possible; Houses of worship may operate at 10 percent occupancy; Additional state parks and certain outdoor recreation guides with COVID-Safe Practices; Masks will be required of everyone in public places, with exceptions for eating, drinking and exercising and medical requirements.   Source information: https://cv.nmhealth.org/2020/05/13/stay-at-home-order-extended/

Retail Businesses should also in addition provide employees with face coverings (when they have contact with public, and these to be cleaned/replaced daily), customers must wear face coverings, hand sanitizer must be provided, 6 ft separation must be kept whenever possible, and sanitation of carts/baskets and high touch areas   Source information: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1507.pdf

Policy_Details: Edwards announced that Louisiana will be in Phase 1 of reopening from May 15 through June 5. The stay-at-home order will lift, though high-risk individuals are encouraged to stay home. All individuals must wear face coverings, practice good hygiene and maintain six feet of distance from non-household members. Certain nonessential businesses can open with occupancy limits. Employers are encouraged to continue allowing employees to telework whenever possible.
In Phase 1, the following businesses can open at 25% capacity with sanitation protocols and spacing for physical distancing: gyms, fitness centers, theaters, places of worship, barber shops, nail salons, hair salons, bars serving food, casinos and video poker, museums, zoos and aquariums. Massage parlors, bars without food permits, tattoo parlors, amusement parks, contact sports, playgrounds, theme parks, adult entertainment venues and other similar businesses will remain closed. Policy_Details: Executive order signed by governor, statewide Cooper signed an executive order modifying the stay-at-home order and transitioning the state into Phase 1 of easing restrictions, effective 5:00 p.m. on May 8. The order will last until at least May 22. The modified order removes the distinction between essential and nonessential businesses. Retail businesses may operate at 50% capacity and must implement health and safety measures for workers and customers. Cloth face coverings are recommended for workers, and teleworking is encouraged whenever possible. In Phase 1, restaurants remain limited to drive-through, takeout and delivery service. Bars, personal care businesses, entertainment venues and gyms will stay closed. Child care facilities can be open during Phase 1, subject to strict cleaning protocols, to serve families of parents who are working or looking for work. Summer day camps can operate in compliance with state guidelines. Phase Level: 1, Phase Details Source information: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO121-Stay-at-Home-Order-3.pdf
http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/COVID-19-Directed-Health-Measures.aspx

Policy_Details: Governor Brian Kemp issued Executive Order on 9/15, providing additional guidance for Empowering a Healthy Georgia in response to COVID-19.No mask requirement statewide, residents only strongly encouraged to wear face coverings as practicable while outside their homes or place of residence, except when eating, drinking, or exercising outdoors.  Local government entities may choose to impose Local Option Face Covering Requirements if their county meets the threshold requirement of cases, so long as this requirement is not applied to certain individuals/activities (i.e. eating/drinking, bona fide religious/medical reason) and shall not result in any fines against any businesses or other establishments.  Fines against any person per offense max $50 and no imprisonment. Enforcement only against individuals and not to be enforced at polling place or residential property, only at private property when owner/occupant consents.     Source information: https://gov.georgia.gov/executive-action/executive-orders/2020-executive-orders

Policy_Details: o Restaurants, bars, breweries, distilleries, and casinos can become operational on or after
May 4, 2020 under strict physical distancing and reduced capacity protocols in
accordance with State guidelines.
 These businesses will be required to close their doors and have all patrons out by
11:30 p.m. Breweries and distilleries shall follow existing laws on closing time.
 The expansions for delivery and takeout services, as provided both in the March
24 and March 26 Directives, are extended through the end of the emergency.
 In addition, restaurants, bars, breweries, distilleries, and casinos that reopen
must adhere to the general and specific guidelines provided in Appendix A,
attached. Phase Level: 1, Phase Details Source information: https://covid19.mt.gov/Portals/223/Documents/04-22-20%20Directive%20and%20Appx%20-%20Reopening%20Phase%20One.pdf?ver=2020-04-22-124954-977

Policy_Details: *phase 2.5 
Governor Roy Cooper signed Executive Order 163 on 9/1: Revised prohibitions and restrictions that move the state in Safer at Home Phase 2.5 measures.
what changes in this order: 
- Mass gathering limits will be increased to 25 people indoors and 50 people outdoors.
- Playgrounds will be allowed to open.
- Museums and aquariums can open at 50% capacity.
- Fitness and competitive physical activity facilities can open at 30% capacity.
- All employers in North Carolina are strongly encouraged to provide face coverings to their employees.
what remains the same: 
- Bars, nightclubs, movie theaters, amusement parks, dance halls and other entertainment facilities will remain closed.
- Restaurants remain subject to capacity limits and other requirements for in-person dining.
- Personal care businesses, such as hair salons, nail salons, barber shops and more remain subject to capacity limits and other requirements.
- Large venues remain subject to the mass gathering limits.
- Wedding receptions and other private events remain subject to the mass gathering limits.
- Face coverings are still required in public.   Source information: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO163-New-Phase-2.5.pdf
http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/COVID-19-Directed-Health-Measures.aspx

Policy_Details: Executive Order 2020-586: Signed 7/19 by Governor Andy Beshear. Effective 7/10 at 5 pm for 30 days. Face coverings must be worn when in line for or inside grocery store/pharmacy, retail establishment, personal care establishment, daycare/childcare facility, restaurant/food establishment, healthcare setting, any other indoor public place where social distancing is not possible, while waiting for or using public transportation or ride sharing, and while in an outdoor public setting where social distancing of 6 feet is not possible between members of different households.  Exceptions for anyone 5 and under, disability making mask wearing not possible safely, when communicating with someone who is hearing impaired or conducting a broadcast, for safety reasons if performing a task that would be deemed unsafe by the state to be wearing a face covering for, when receiving a service that requires the face to be uncovered, for safety/security reasons, when actively exercising, swimming, eating or drinking.    Source information: https://govsite-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/A59NLcxVTFG7ioyvncMY_20200709_Executive-Order_State-of-Emergency.pdf

Policy_Details: Executive Order 54 by Governor Bill Lee signed 7/3 regarding face coverings: all persons encouraged to wear face coverings in public places.
Further, county mayors in the 89 counties that do not have county health departments have authority to issue orders requiring face coverings so long as they do not require face coverings to be worn while driving (unless for hire), by someone 12 years or younger, those with relevant breathing/health conditions, those unable to remove face coverings without assistance, while eating or drinking, while outdoors unless 6 ft distance not possible, while social distance is kept, when face covering poses security or safety risk, while in a Houses of Worship, or while in a voting site.    Source information: https://publications.tnsosfiles.com/pub/execorders/exec-orders-lee54.pdf

Policy_Details: Phase 2: Gov. Beshear announced the second phase of reopening the commonwealth’s economy
All businesses should follow the 10 rules of staying healthy at work as well as industry-specific guidance, which will be issued as soon as possible. The new tentative dates for reopening are: May 9 - houses of worship open to 33%
May 22 – Restaurants, with limited 33% capacity and outdoor seating, May 25 - reopening of personal care establishments 
June 1 – Movie theaters, fitness centers June 10 - houses of worship to 50%
June 11 – Campgrounds, public and private
June 15 – Child care, with reduced capacity; and potentially low-touch and outdoor youth sports
The Governor added that Phase 3 is coming July 1 with bars, with limitations, and gatherings up to 50 people allowed. Phase Level: 2, Phase Details Source information: https://kentucky.gov/Pages/Activity-stream.aspx?n=GovernorBeshear&prId=156, https://govstatus.egov.com/ky-healthy-at-work

Policy_Details: *phase 2.5 
Governor Roy Cooper signed Executive Order 163 on 9/1: Revised prohibitions and restrictions that move the state in Safer at Home Phase 2.5 measures.
what changes in this order: 
- Mass gathering limits will be increased to 25 people indoors and 50 people outdoors.
- Playgrounds will be allowed to open.
- Fitness and competitive physical activity facilities can open at 30% capacity.
what remains the same:

Policy_Details: "The previous statewide Stay-at-Home and mass gatherings orders are lifted and mass gatherings of more than 10 individuals are prohibited. [...] Industries or functions that are already in operation pursuant to KEFF may continue to function while, if possible, avoiding gatherings of more than 10 individuals where social distancing measures are difficult to maintain. Any local government that decides to impose equal or more stringent restrictions during this phase is permitted to do so, except with regards to essential functions in KEFF. Any federal restrictions imposed and still in effect must be followed." (p.9 of pdf in Source)   Source information: https://covid.ks.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Reopen-Kansas-Framework-v5-1.pdf

Policy_Details: The Michigan Department of Health and Human Services eased mask requirements for fully vaccinated people, reflecting current CDC guidance.   Source information: https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-98178_98455-559589--,00.html
Wichita County Policy End
